Effects of web‐based diabetes education on knowledge retention in adult general population: An experiment

Author: Cenčič, Ajda1; Bajec, Saša2; Žvanut, Boštjan3    1 Primary Healthcare Center Koper, Diabetes Outpatient Clinic, Koper, Slovenia2 Primary Healthcare Center Nova Gorica, Nova Gorica, Slovenia3 Department of Nursing, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Primorska, Izola, Slovenia bostjan.zvanut@fvz.upr.si

Publication info: Cenčič, Ajda; Bajec, Saša; Žvanut, Boštjan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effects-web-based-diabetes-education-on-knowledge/docview/3062247339/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Objective: To conduct a study to improve diabetes knowledge through a web-based diabetes course in the general adult population. We hypothesised that participation in a web-based diabetes course would have a positive impact on diabetes knowledge retention. Methods: Participants were randomly assigned to an experimental or control group. Participants in the experimental group attended an interactive web-based diabetes course. The Diabetes Knowledge Questionnaire (DKQ24) was used to assess the diabetes knowledge levels. The DKQ24 was completed at the beginning and end of the observation period of 3 months. The experimental group also completed it immediately after the intervention. Results: At the end of the observation period, a statistically significant difference in the mean rank of DKQ24 scores was found in favor of the experimental group ( p < .001). The results of the experimental group had a lower interquartile range (IQR = 3) than those of the control group (IQR = 5). Conclusions: This study suggests that providing a web-based diabetes course to the general population is effective and can improve diabetes knowledge and retention. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2024 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ajda&amp;aulast=Cen%C4%8Di%C4%8D&amp;atitle=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;stitle=Public+Health+Nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fphn.13304&amp;title=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;volume=41&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=555&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Exploring the Dynamics of Technological Decline through the History of a Soviet Computer “Ural” (1955-1990)

Author: Koretsky Zahar1    ; Zeiss Ragna2; van Lente Harro21 Laboratoire Interdisciplinaire Sciences Innovations Sociétés (LISIS), Université Gustave Eiffel, Marne-la-Vallée, France2 Maastricht University Science, Technology and Society (MUSTS) Group, Maastricht University, the Netherlands

Publication info: Koretsky Zahar; Zeiss Ragna; van Lente Harro. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/exploring-dynamics-technological-decline-through/docview/3058890222/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Literature on technological decline and related concepts is growing. We aim to advance theorizations of the dynamics of technological decline by mobilizing the concept of sociotechnical configuration and a metaphor of its “unraveling.” We take as a case study the declined Soviet computer series Ural . Ural was once among the top three most used computers in the former Soviet Union, but went into decline and got lost even before the dissolution of the country. We find that technological decline is not a trivial process, it is not guaranteed to be gradual but can feature sudden shifts. These shifts can be drops of production and loss of knowledge, as well as efforts to push back. Policy could make use of ongoing processes of decline and try to replicate the effect of the decline of Ural via cessation of access to materials and competences and delegitimation of the technology.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Koretsky+Zahar&amp;atitle=Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Technological+Decline+through+the+History+of+a+Soviet+Computer+%26ldquo%3BUral%26rdquo%3B+%281955-1990%29&amp;stitle=Science%2C+Technology+%26+Human+Values&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F01622439221130139&amp;title=Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Technological+Decline+through+the+History+of+a+Soviet+Computer+%E2%80%9CUral%E2%80%9D+%281955-1990%29&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=578&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Koretsky+Zahar&amp;atitle=Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Technological+Decline+through+the+History+of+a+Soviet+Computer+%26ldquo%3BUral%26rdquo%3B+%281955-1990%29&amp;stitle=Science%2C+Technology+%26+Human+Values&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F01622439221130139&amp;title=Exploring+the+Dynamics+of+Technological+Decline+through+the+History+of+a+Soviet+Computer+%E2%80%9CUral%E2%80%9D+%281955-1990%29&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=578&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Embedding Nursing Ethics Within Teaching Strategies in Nurse Residency Programs

Author: West, Rebecca S; Axel-Adams, Robyn M; Wocial, Lucia D    

Publication info: West, Rebecca S; Axel-Adams, Robyn M; Wocial, Lucia D. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/embedding-nursing-ethics-within-teaching/docview/3049716446/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Exposing new nurses to theoretical teaching strategies that help them to navigate the ethical challenges in clinical practice is essential for retention and long-term job satisfaction. This article explores the rationale for teaching ethics content in nurse residency programs and ways to navigate ethical decision-making in the clinical setting. Examples of evidence-informed teaching strategies that enhance knowledge retention and reduce the gap between ethical theory and practice are included.Exposing new nurses to theoretical teaching strategies that help them to navigate the ethical challenges in clinical practice is essential for retention and long-term job satisfaction. This article explores the rationale for teaching ethics content in nurse residency programs and ways to navigate ethical decision-making in the clinical setting. Examples of evidence-informed teaching strategies that enhance knowledge retention and reduce the gap between ethical theory and practice are included.

____________________________________________________________

Effects of web‐based diabetes education on knowledge retention in adult general population: An experiment

Author: Cenčič, Ajda1; Bajec, Saša2; Žvanut, Boštjan3    1 Primary Healthcare Center Koper, Diabetes Outpatient Clinic, Koper, Slovenia; Department of Nursing, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Primorska, Izola, Slovenia2 Primary Healthcare Center Nova Gorica, Nova Gorica, Slovenia3 Department of Nursing, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Primorska, Izola, Slovenia

Publication info: Cenčič, Ajda; Bajec, Saša; Žvanut, Boštjan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effects-web-based-diabetes-education-on-knowledge/docview/3038260684/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Objective To conduct a study to improve diabetes knowledge through a web‐based diabetes course in the general adult population. We hypothesised that participation in a web‐based diabetes course would have a positive impact on diabetes knowledge retention. Methods Participants were randomly assigned to an experimental or control group. Participants in the experimental group attended an interactive web‐based diabetes course. The Diabetes Knowledge Questionnaire (DKQ24) was used to assess the diabetes knowledge levels. The DKQ24 was completed at the beginning and end of the observation period of 3 months. The experimental group also completed it immediately after the intervention. Results At the end of the observation period, a statistically significant difference in the mean rank of DKQ24 scores was found in favor of the experimental group ( p  < .001). The results of the experimental group had a lower interquartile range (IQR = 3) than those of the control group (IQR = 5). Conclusions This study suggests that providing a web‐based diabetes course to the general population is effective and can improve diabetes knowledge and retention.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ajda&amp;aulast=Cen%C4%8Di%C4%8D&amp;atitle=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;stitle=Public+Health+Nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fphn.13304&amp;title=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;volume=41&amp;issue=3&amp;date=May%2FJun+2024&amp;spage=555&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ajda&amp;aulast=Cen%C4%8Di%C4%8D&amp;atitle=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;stitle=Public+Health+Nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fphn.13304&amp;title=Effects+of+web%E2%80%90based+diabetes+education+on+knowledge+retention+in+adult+general+population%3A+An+experiment&amp;volume=41&amp;issue=3&amp;date=May%2FJun+2024&amp;spage=555&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Diabetes mellitus; Diabetes; Retention; Statistical analysis; Webs; Knowledge; Interactive control

Title: Effects of web‐based diabetes education on knowledge retention in adult general population: An experiment

Leveraging transportation providers to deploy lay first responder (LFR) programs in three sub-Saharan African countries without formal emergency medical services: Evaluating longitudinal impact and cost-effectiveness

Author: Delaney, Peter G1; Eisner, Zachary J2; Pine, Haleigh3; Klapow, Max4; Thullah, Alfred Harun5; Bamuleke, Richard6; Nuur, Issa Mohamet7; Raghavendran, Krishnan21 Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH, USA delanep@ccf.org2 University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA3 Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri, USA4 Oxford University, Oxford, Engl and, United Kingdom5 LFR International, Makeni, Sierra Leone6 Uganda Red Cross Society, Iganga, Uganda7 Red Cross of Chad, Am Timan, Chad

Publication info: Delaney, Peter G; Eisner, Zachary J; Pine, Haleigh; Klapow, Max; Thullah, Alfred Harun; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/leveraging-transportation-providers-deploy-lay/docview/3003437981/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: In 2019, the World Health Assembly declared emergency care essential to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. Few sub-Saharan African (SSA) countries have developed robust approaches to sustainably deliver emergency medical services (EMS) at scale, as high-income country models are financially impractical. Innovative reassessment of EMS delivery in resource-limited settings is necessary as timely emergency care access can substantially reduce mortality. INTRODUCTION In 2019, the World Health Assembly declared emergency care essential to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. Few sub-Saharan African (SSA) countries have developed robust approaches to sustainably deliver emergency medical services (EMS) at scale, as high-income country models are financially impractical. Innovative reassessment of EMS delivery in resource-limited settings is necessary as timely emergency care access can substantially reduce mortality.We developed the Lay First Responder (LFR) program by training 1,291 pre-existing motorcycle taxi drivers, a predominant form of short-distance transport in sub-Saharan Africa, to provide trauma care and transport for road traffic injuries. Three pilot programs were launched in staggered fashion between 2016 and 2019 in West, Central, and East Africa and a 5.5 h curriculum was iteratively developed to train first responders. Longitudinal data on patient impact (patient demographics, injury characteristics, and treatment rendered), emergency care knowledge acquisition/retention, and social/financial effects of LFR training were collected and pooled across three sites for collective analysis. Novel cost-effectiveness ratios were calculated based on prospective cost data from each site. Previously projected aggregate disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) addressable by LFRs were used to inform cost-effectiveness ratios($USD cost per DALY averted). Cost-effectiveness ratios were then compared against African per capita gross domestic product (GDP), following WHOCHOICE guidelines, which state ratios less than GDP per capita are "very cost-effective." MATERIALS AND METHODS We developed the Lay First Responder (LFR) program by training 1,291 pre-existing motorcycle taxi drivers, a predominant form of short-distance transport in sub-Saharan Africa, to provide trauma care and transport for road traffic injuries. Three pilot programs were launched in staggered fashion between 2016 and 2019 in West, Central, and East Africa and a 5.5 h curriculum was iteratively developed to train first responders. Longitudinal data on patient impact (patient demographics, injury characteristics, and treatment rendered), emergency care knowledge acquisition/retention, and social/financial effects of LFR training were collected and pooled across three sites for collective analysis. Novel cost-effectiveness ratios were calculated based on prospective cost data from each site. Previously projected aggregate disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) addressable by LFRs were used to inform cost-effectiveness ratios($USD cost per DALY averted). Cost-effectiveness ratios were then compared against African per capita gross domestic product (GDP), following WHOCHOICE guidelines, which state ratios less than GDP per capita are "very cost-effective."In 2,171 total patient encounters across all three pilot sites, LFRs most frequently provided hemorrhage control in 61 % of patient encounters and patient transport by motorcycle in 98.5 %. Median pre-/post-test scores improved by 34.1 percentage points (39.5% vs.73.6 %, p < 0.0001) with significant knowledge retention at six months. 75 % of initial participants remain voluntarily involved 3 years post-course, reporting increased local stature and customer acquisition(income 32.0 % greater than non-trained counterparts). Locally sourced first-aid materials cost $6.54USD/participant. Cost-effectiveness analysis demonstrated cost per DALY averted=$51.65USD. RESULTS In 2,171 total patient encounters across all three pilot sites, LFRs most frequently provided hemorrhage control in 61 % of patient encounters and patient transport by motorcycle in 98.5 %. Median pre-/post-test scores improved by 34.1 percentage points (39.5% vs.73.6 %, p < 0.0001) with significant knowledge retention at six months. 75 % of initial participants remain voluntarily involved 3 years post-course, reporting increased local stature and customer acquisition(income 32.0 % greater than non-trained counterparts). Locally sourced first-aid materials cost $6.54USD/participant. Cost-effectiveness analysis demonstrated cost per DALY averted=$51.65USD.LFR training is highly cost-effective according to WHOCHOICE guidelines and expands emergency care access. The LFR program may be an alternative approach to formal ambulance-reliant EMS that are cost-prohibitive in resource-limited, sub-Saharan African settings. A novel social/financial mechanism appears to incentivize long-term voluntary LFR involvement, which may sustain programs in resource-limited settings. CONCLUSION LFR training is highly cost-effective according to WHOCHOICE guidelines and expands emergency care access. The LFR program may be an alternative approach to formal ambulance-reliant EMS that are cost-prohibitive in resource-limited, sub-Saharan African settings. A novel social/financial mechanism appears to incentivize long-term voluntary LFR involvement, which may sustain programs in resource-limited settings.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Peter&amp;aulast=Delaney&amp;atitle=Leveraging+transportation+providers+to+deploy+lay+first+responder+%28LFR%29+programs+in+three+sub-Saharan+African+countries+without+formal+emergency+medical+services%3A+Evaluating+longitudinal+impact+and+cost-effectiveness&amp;stitle=Injury&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.injury.2024.111505&amp;title=Leveraging+transportation+providers+to+deploy+lay+first+responder+%28LFR%29+programs+in+three+sub-Saharan+African+countries+without+formal+emergency+medical+services%3A+Evaluating+longitudinal+impact+and+cost-effectiveness&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=111505&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Peter&amp;aulast=Delaney&amp;atitle=Leveraging+transportation+providers+to+deploy+lay+first+responder+%28LFR%29+programs+in+three+sub-Saharan+African+countries+without+formal+emergency+medical+services%3A+Evaluating+longitudinal+impact+and+cost-effectiveness&amp;stitle=Injury&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.injury.2024.111505&amp;title=Leveraging+transportation+providers+to+deploy+lay+first+responder+%28LFR%29+programs+in+three+sub-Saharan+African+countries+without+formal+emergency+medical+services%3A+Evaluating+longitudinal+impact+and+cost-effectiveness&amp;volume=55&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=111505&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Leveraging transportation providers to deploy lay first responder (LFR) programs in three sub-Saharan African countries without formal emergency medical services: Evaluating longitudinal impact and cost-effectiveness

Effects of web-based diabetes education on knowledge retention in adult general population: An experiment

Author: Cenčič, Ajda1; Bajec, Saša2; Žvanut, Boštjan3    1 Primary Healthcare Center Koper, Diabetes Outpatient Clinic, Koper, Slovenia; Department of Nursing, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Primorska, Izola, Slovenia2 Primary Healthcare Center Nova Gorica, Nova Gorica, Slovenia3 Department of Nursing, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Primorska, Izola, Slovenia

Publication info: Cenčič, Ajda; Bajec, Saša; Žvanut, Boštjan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effects-web-based-diabetes-education-on-knowledge/docview/2972703814/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: To conduct a study to improve diabetes knowledge through a web-based diabetes course in the general adult population. We hypothesised that participation in a web-based diabetes course would have a positive impact on diabetes knowledge retention. OBJECTIVE To conduct a study to improve diabetes knowledge through a web-based diabetes course in the general adult population. We hypothesised that participation in a web-based diabetes course would have a positive impact on diabetes knowledge retention.Participants were randomly assigned to an experimental or control group. Participants in the experimental group attended an interactive web-based diabetes course. The Diabetes Knowledge Questionnaire (DKQ24) was used to assess the diabetes knowledge levels. The DKQ24 was completed at the beginning and end of the observation period of 3 months. The experimental group also completed it immediately after the intervention. METHODS Participants were randomly assigned to an experimental or control group. Participants in the experimental group attended an interactive web-based diabetes course. The Diabetes Knowledge Questionnaire (DKQ24) was used to assess the diabetes knowledge levels. The DKQ24 was completed at the beginning and end of the observation period of 3 months. The experimental group also completed it immediately after the intervention.At the end of the observation period, a statistically significant difference in the mean rank of DKQ24 scores was found in favor of the experimental group (p < .001). The results of the experimental group had a lower interquartile range (IQR = 3) than those of the control group (IQR = 5). RESULTS At the end of the observation period, a statistically significant difference in the mean rank of DKQ24 scores was found in favor of the experimental group (p < .001). The results of the experimental group had a lower interquartile range (IQR = 3) than those of the control group (IQR = 5).This study suggests that providing a web-based diabetes course to the general population is effective and can improve diabetes knowledge and retention. CONCLUSIONS This study suggests that providing a web-based diabetes course to the general population is effective and can improve diabetes knowledge and retention.

Retraining transplant pharmacy staff to reduce Medicare Part B prescription billing errors post-transplant

Author: Rodriguez, Keren; Ray, Chelsea; Mitchell, Kirsten; Osman, Sarah; Vallone, Carey; Wilson, Michael; Hayes, Chris; Staff, Genny; Chelewski, Rachel; Cruchelow, Katie R; Zuckerman, Autumn D

Publication info: Rodriguez, Keren; Ray, Chelsea; Mitchell, Kirsten; Osman, Sarah; Vallone, Carey; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/retraining-transplant-pharmacy-staff-reduce/docview/2934268537/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Medicare Part B (MedB) imposes penalties for certain errors in prescription billing of post-transplant medications, which can greatly affect pharmacy revenue. To prevent MedB billing fines, pharmacy staff must be cognizant of specific MedB requirements. BACKGROUND Medicare Part B (MedB) imposes penalties for certain errors in prescription billing of post-transplant medications, which can greatly affect pharmacy revenue. To prevent MedB billing fines, pharmacy staff must be cognizant of specific MedB requirements.This quality improvement project aimed to retrain certified pharmacy technicians (CPhTs) on common billing errors and evaluate changes in error rates and potential fines after retraining. We aimed to determine whether retraining CPhTs minimizes MedB prescription billing errors and reduces potential fines owed by the Vanderbilt Transplant Pharmacy (VTP) to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS). OBJECTIVE This quality improvement project aimed to retrain certified pharmacy technicians (CPhTs) on common billing errors and evaluate changes in error rates and potential fines after retraining. We aimed to determine whether retraining CPhTs minimizes MedB prescription billing errors and reduces potential fines owed by the Vanderbilt Transplant Pharmacy (VTP) to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS).This was a single-center, quality improvement study including post-transplant patients with at least one MedB prescription billing error who filled prescriptions through VTP. All CPhTs involved in MedB prescription billing received retraining focused on the top 3 errors in MedB billing identified at VTP: early refills, missing relationship of caller to patient and residence of patient on order documentation, or no day supply remaining recorded on the order file. Retraining consisted of developing a training checklist, testing current knowledge levels, individualized nonpunitive coaching based on technician specific errors, and retesting for knowledge retention. Outcomes included the number of prescriptions with at least one MedB prescription billing error and the projected amount of dollars fined owing to errors recorded during the 3 months before and 3 months after retraining. METHODS This was a single-center, quality improvement study including post-transplant patients with at least one MedB prescription billing error who filled prescriptions through VTP. All CPhTs involved in MedB prescription billing received retraining focused on the top 3 errors in MedB billing identified at VTP: early refills, missing relationship of caller to patient and residence of patient on order documentation, or no day supply remaining recorded on the order file. Retraining consisted of developing a training checklist, testing current knowledge levels, individualized nonpunitive coaching based on technician specific errors, and retesting for knowledge retention. Outcomes included the number of prescriptions with at least one MedB prescription billing error and the projected amount of dollars fined owing to errors recorded during the 3 months before and 3 months after retraining.Fourteen CPhTs received retraining. Average refill too soon errors decreased by 37.5% (10.7% vs. 6.7%), average missing relationship by 21.7% (7.7% vs. 6%), and day supply errors by 39.7% (1.7% vs. 1%). Error reductions equaled a 28.2% decrease (approximately $12,700) in potential fines. RESULTS Fourteen CPhTs received retraining. Average refill too soon errors decreased by 37.5% (10.7% vs. 6.7%), average missing relationship by 21.7% (7.7% vs. 6%), and day supply errors by 39.7% (1.7% vs. 1%). Error reductions equaled a 28.2% decrease (approximately $12,700) in potential fines.Retraining focused on MedB billing error successfully reduced error frequency and fines from CMS. MedB billing error fines can be costly for pharmacies dispensing high-cost medications; therefore, identifying common errors and training staff can be useful and financially prudent. CONCLUSION Retraining focused on MedB billing error successfully reduced error frequency and fines from CMS. MedB billing error fines can be costly for pharmacies dispensing high-cost medications; therefore, identifying common errors and training staff can be useful and financially prudent.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Keren&amp;aulast=Rodriguez&amp;atitle=Retraining+transplant+pharmacy+staff+to+reduce+Medicare+Part+B+prescription+billing+errors+post-transplant&amp;stitle=Journal+of+the+American+Pharmacists+Association+%3A+JAPhA&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.japh.2024.102059&amp;title=Retraining+transplant+pharmacy+staff+to+reduce+Medicare+Part+B+prescription+billing+errors+post-transplant&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=3&amp;date=May-Jun+2024&amp;spage=102059&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Keren&amp;aulast=Rodriguez&amp;atitle=Retraining+transplant+pharmacy+staff+to+reduce+Medicare+Part+B+prescription+billing+errors+post-transplant&amp;stitle=Journal+of+the+American+Pharmacists+Association+%3A+JAPhA&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.japh.2024.102059&amp;title=Retraining+transplant+pharmacy+staff+to+reduce+Medicare+Part+B+prescription+billing+errors+post-transplant&amp;volume=64&amp;issue=3&amp;date=May-Jun+2024&amp;spage=102059&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Retraining transplant pharmacy staff to reduce Medicare Part B prescription billing errors post-transplant

____________________________________________________________

Digital human ergonomics training for remote office workers: Comparing a novel method to a traditional online format

Author: Aguilar, Kaysey N1; Smith, Matthew Lee2; Payne, Stephanie C3; Zhao, Hongwei4; Benden, Mark11 Texas A & M University, School of Public Health, Department of Environmental & Occupational Health, 212 Adriance Lab Road, College Station, TX, 77843, USA kaysey_nicole@tamu.edu; mbenden@tamu.edu2 Texas A & M University, School of Public Health, Department of Health Behavior, 212 Adriance Lab Road, College Station, TX, 77843, USA matthew.smith@tamu.edu3 Texas A & M University, College of Arts and Sciences, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, 230 Psychology Building, 4235 TAMU, College Station, TX, 77843, USA scp@tamu.edu4 Texas A & M University, School of Public Health, Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, 212 Adriance Lab Road, College Station, TX, 77843, USA hongweizhao@tamu.edu

Publication info: Aguilar, Kaysey N; Smith, Matthew Lee; Payne, Stephanie C; Zhao, Hongwei; Benden, Mark. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/digital-human-ergonomics-training-remote-office/docview/2926073915/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This randomized controlled trial investigated the effectiveness of an online ergonomics training program with a digital human compared to an online ergonomics training program without a digital human. OBJECTIVE This randomized controlled trial investigated the effectiveness of an online ergonomics training program with a digital human compared to an online ergonomics training program without a digital human.Remote office workers (n = 138) were randomly assigned to either a digital human training, a traditional webpage training without a digital human, or a control group. Musculoskeletal discomfort, knowledge retention, and behavior change were measured. METHOD Remote office workers (n = 138) were randomly assigned to either a digital human training, a traditional webpage training without a digital human, or a control group. Musculoskeletal discomfort, knowledge retention, and behavior change were measured.The overall group differences for increased behavior change and knowledge retention were statistically significant (p   0.05). RESULTS The overall group differences for increased behavior change and knowledge retention were statistically significant (p   0.05).Digital humans have the potential to meet large-scale remote worker training needs. CONCLUSION Digital humans have the potential to meet large-scale remote worker training needs.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Kaysey&amp;aulast=Aguilar&amp;atitle=Digital+human+ergonomics+training+for+remote+office+workers%3A+Comparing+a+novel+method+to+a+traditional+online+format&amp;stitle=Applied+ergonomics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.apergo.2024.104239&amp;title=Digital+human+ergonomics+training+for+remote+office+workers%3A+Comparing+a+novel+method+to+a+traditional+online+format&amp;volume=117&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=104239&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Training nurses in an international emergency medical team using a serious role-playing game: a retrospective comparative analysis

Author: Hu, Hai1; Lai, Xiaoqin2; Yan, Longping31 Emergency Management Office of West China Hospital, Sichuan University, The street address: No. 37. Guoxue Road, Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China; China International Emergency Medical Team (Sichuan), Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China; Emergency Medical Rescue Base, Sichuan University, Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China huhai@wchscu.cn2 China International Emergency Medical Team (Sichuan), Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China; Day Surgery Center, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China; Department of Thoracic Surgery, West China Tianfu Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu City , Sichuan Province, China3 West China School of Nursing, Sichuan University, Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, China; West China School of Public Health, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China; West China Fourth Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, China

Publication info: Hu, Hai; Lai, Xiaoqin; Yan, Longping. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/training-nurses-international-emergency-medical/docview/3045117449/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Although game-based applications have been used in disaster medicine education, no serious computer games have been designed specifically for training these nurses in an IEMT setting. To address this need, we developed a serious computer game called the IEMTtraining game. In this game, players assume the roles of IEMT nurses, assess patient injuries in a virtual environment, and provide suitable treatment options. BACKGROUND Although game-based applications have been used in disaster medicine education, no serious computer games have been designed specifically for training these nurses in an IEMT setting. To address this need, we developed a serious computer game called the IEMTtraining game. In this game, players assume the roles of IEMT nurses, assess patient injuries in a virtual environment, and provide suitable treatment options.The design of this study is a retrospective comparative analysis. The research was conducted with 209 nurses in a hospital. The data collection process of this study was conducted at the 2019-2020 academic year. A retrospective comparative analysis was conducted on the pre-, post-, and final test scores of nurses in the IEMT. Additionally, a survey questionnaire was distributed to trainees to gather insights into teaching methods that were subsequently analyzed. METHODS The design of this study is a retrospective comparative analysis. The research was conducted with 209 nurses in a hospital. The data collection process of this study was conducted at the 2019-2020 academic year. A retrospective comparative analysis was conducted on the pre-, post-, and final test scores of nurses in the IEMT. Additionally, a survey questionnaire was distributed to trainees to gather insights into teaching methods that were subsequently analyzed.There was a significant difference in the overall test scores between the two groups, with the game group demonstrating superior performance compared to the control group (odds ratio = 1.363, p value = 0.010). The survey results indicated that the game group exhibited higher learning motivation scores and lower cognitive load compared with the lecture group. RESULTS There was a significant difference in the overall test scores between the two groups, with the game group demonstrating superior performance compared to the control group (odds ratio = 1.363, p value = 0.010). The survey results indicated that the game group exhibited higher learning motivation scores and lower cognitive load compared with the lecture group.The IEMT training game developed by the instructor team is a promising and effective method for training nurses in disaster rescue within IEMTs. The game equips the trainees with the necessary skills and knowledge to respond effectively to emergencies. It is easily comprehended, enhances knowledge retention and motivation to learn, and reduces cognitive load. CONCLUSIONS The IEMT training game developed by the instructor team is a promising and effective method for training nurses in disaster rescue within IEMTs. The game equips the trainees with the necessary skills and knowledge to respond effectively to emergencies. It is easily comprehended, enhances knowledge retention and motivation to learn, and reduces cognitive load.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Hai&amp;aulast=Hu&amp;atitle=Training+nurses+in+an+international+emergency+medical+team+using+a+serious+role-playing+game%3A+a+retrospective+comparative+analysis&amp;stitle=BMC+medical+education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs12909-024-05442-x&amp;title=Training+nurses+in+an+international+emergency+medical+team+using+a+serious+role-playing+game%3A+a+retrospective+comparative+analysis&amp;volume=24&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=432&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Hai&amp;aulast=Hu&amp;atitle=Training+nurses+in+an+international+emergency+medical+team+using+a+serious+role-playing+game%3A+a+retrospective+comparative+analysis&amp;stitle=BMC+medical+education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs12909-024-05442-x&amp;title=Training+nurses+in+an+international+emergency+medical+team+using+a+serious+role-playing+game%3A+a+retrospective+comparative+analysis&amp;volume=24&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=432&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Score race”: A perspective of Cai Nuoc high school students

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/score-race-perspective-cai-nuoc-high-school/docview/3043399728/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The scoring race is a phenomenon where students participate in learning just for the sake of their scores; Schools, families, and society only judge students by their grades. The study was carried out to assess the status of the scoring race and propose some solutions to reduce the negative influence of this phenomenon. Cai Nuoc High School, Ca Mau Province - the most remote area in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam was selected for the case study. A cross-sectional survey model combined with quantitative research was used in this study. The number of students answering the question was 245, and the questionnaire was designed through Google Form in November 2021. The research results show that the majority of students participated in the scoring race (3.47±1.29), most of the students liked to get high scores (3.46±1.42) and were disappointed due to the loss of knowledge (4.16±0.98) and careless (4.82±0.61). Besides, the majority of students think that society judges them only by their scores (4.37±0.96); they are under a lot of pressure because of their grades (3.76±1.20), pressure from teachers (3.39±0.92, accounting for 82.1%), students have ever violated the test because of scores (4.10±1.24), had conflicts with classmates because of scores (3.36±1.34). Thus, in order to lessen the “score race” adverse effect, first of all, schools need to innovate teaching content, diversify teaching methods, teaching techniques, and methods of assessing results learning outcomes; families and society need to change their perception of students abilities; Students need to orient their learning goals, develop a study plan, actively participate in all learning activities to develop the necessary qualities and competencies.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=&amp;atitle=Score+race%26rdquo%3B%3A+A+perspective+of+Cai+Nuoc+high+school+students&amp;stitle=AIP+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1063%2F5.0200982&amp;title=Score+race%E2%80%9D%3A+A+perspective+of+Cai+Nuoc+high+school+students&amp;volume=3052&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Subject: Teaching; Teaching methods; Students; Learning

Title: Score race”: A perspective of Cai Nuoc high school students

Results of integrating short VR exercises into traditional CBTs

Author: Hannah, Richard1    1 School of Public Health, Texas A & M University, College Station, TX, US dhannah@tamu.edu

Publication info: Hannah, Richard. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/results-integrating-short-vr-exercises-into/docview/3065077263/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The purpose of this research was to investigate the effects of short virtual reality (VR) exercises on knowledge retention for adult learners at a contractor safety training organisation supporting the energy industry who took computer-based training (CBT) courses. The intent was to simulate a delay period similar to that experienced by contractors who support work in the energy industry to determine if traditional CBT can be made more effective for stimulating greater transfer of learning with the addition of VR exercises. The experimental group was exposed to CBTs augmented by VR exercises that reinforced the CBT course learning objectives. The control group for this research took the same CBT course without short VR exercises. A quantitative analysis was performed on data collected from a course exam provided immediately after the course delivery and from a separate follow-up quiz delivered 3 days after the course(s) completion. Data from these testing instruments were analysed to determine the participant’s likelihood of remembering content from the CBT courses and if there was greater knowledge retention of the course learning objectives and procedures within the experimental group than within the control group. The results found a non-statistically significant relationship between the two groups; however, trends between the groups show that there are benefits for transfer of learning when using short VR exercises compared to those groups without short VR exercises. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2025 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Richard&amp;aulast=Hannah&amp;atitle=Results+of+integrating+short+VR+exercises+into+traditional+CBTs&amp;stitle=Research+in+Learning+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.25304%2Frlt.v32.3257&amp;title=Results+of+integrating+short+VR+exercises+into+traditional+CBTs&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=3257&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

The good lecture

Author: Lüscher, Michael1; Konge, Lars2; Tanggaard, Lene3; Andersen, Steven Arild Wuyts41 Sundhedshuset, Aarhus2 Copenhagen Academy for Medical Education and Simulation (CAMES), Københavns Universitetshospital - Rigshospitalet3 Institut for Kommunikation og Psykologi, Aalborg Universitet4 Copenhagen Academy for Medical Education and Simulation (CAMES), Københavns Universitetshospital - Rigshospitalet; Copenhagen Hearing and Balance Center, Afdeling for Øre- Næse og Halskirurgi, Københavns Universitetshospital - Rigshospitalet

Publication info: Lüscher, Michael; Konge, Lars; Tanggaard, Lene; Andersen, Steven Arild Wuyts. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/good-lecture/docview/3051425067/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Postgraduate medical education often relies on the traditional lecture model with low knowledge retention rates of 5-20%. Cognitive overload from excessive information during lectures diminishes learning efficacy. To optimise learning, evidence suggests prioritising active engagement, streamlining visual aids, introducing clinical scenarios, and incorporating audience response systems may further enhance retention and comprehension. In conclusion, the traditional lecture must evolve into more interactive and engaging modalities to facilitate increased participant long-term learning as summarised in this review.Postgraduate medical education often relies on the traditional lecture model with low knowledge retention rates of 5-20%. Cognitive overload from excessive information during lectures diminishes learning efficacy. To optimise learning, evidence suggests prioritising active engagement, streamlining visual aids, introducing clinical scenarios, and incorporating audience response systems may further enhance retention and comprehension. In conclusion, the traditional lecture must evolve into more interactive and engaging modalities to facilitate increased participant long-term learning as summarised in this review.

Wild Edible Plants Used in Dalmatian Zagora (Croatia)

Author: Ninčević Runjić, Tonka; Jug-Dujaković, Marija; Runjić, Marko; Łuczaj, Łukasz

Publication info: Ninčević Runjić, Tonka; Jug-Dujaković, Marija; Runjić, Marko; Łuczaj, Łukasz. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/wild-edible-plants-used-dalmatian-zagora-croatia/docview/3153602603/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: ENG English ENG Background: Dalmatian Zagora has experienced significant depopulation trends over recent decades. The area is very interesting because of its rich biodiversity of species as well as its history of the use of wild foods. Since there is a danger of permanent loss of knowledge on the use of wild edibles, we focused our research on recording traditions local to this area. Methods: We conducted interviews with 180 residents. Results: A record was made of 136 species of wild food plants and 22 species of edible mushrooms gathered in the area. The most frequently collected species are Rubus ulmifolius Schott, Cornus mas L., Portulaca oleracea L., Asparagus acutifolius L., Sonchus spp., Morus spp., Taraxacum spp., Amaranthus retroflexus L., Cichorium intybus L., and Dioscorea communis (L.) Caddick & Wilkin. Conclusions: The list of taxa used is typical for other (sub-)Mediterranean parts of Croatia; however, more fungi species are used. The most important finding of the paper is probably the recording of Legousia speculum-veneris (L.) Chaix, a wild vegetable used in the area.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tonka&amp;aulast=Nin%C4%8Devi%C4%87+Runji%C4%87&amp;atitle=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;stitle=Plants&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fplants13081079&amp;title=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tonka&amp;aulast=Nin%C4%8Devi%C4%87+Runji%C4%87&amp;atitle=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;stitle=Plants&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fplants13081079&amp;title=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

____________________________________________________________

Wild Edible Plants Used in Dalmatian Zagora (Croatia)

Author: Ninčević Runjić, Tonka1    ; Jug-Dujaković, Marija1; Runjić, Marko1    ; Łuczaj, Łukasz2    1 Institute for Adriatic Crops and Karst Reclamation, Put Duilova 11, 21000 Split, Croatia2 Institute of Biology, University of Rzeszów, Ul. Zelwerowicza 4/451, Building D9, 35-601 Rzeszów, Poland

Publication info: Ninčević Runjić, Tonka; Jug-Dujaković, Marija; Runjić, Marko; Łuczaj, Łukasz. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/wild-edible-plants-used-dalmatian-zagora-croatia/docview/3047949288/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Dalmatian Zagora has experienced significant depopulation trends over recent decades. The area is very interesting because of its rich biodiversity of species as well as its history of the use of wild foods. Since there is a danger of permanent loss of knowledge on the use of wild edibles, we focused our research on recording traditions local to this area. BACKGROUND Dalmatian Zagora has experienced significant depopulation trends over recent decades. The area is very interesting because of its rich biodiversity of species as well as its history of the use of wild foods. Since there is a danger of permanent loss of knowledge on the use of wild edibles, we focused our research on recording traditions local to this area.We conducted interviews with 180 residents. METHODS We conducted interviews with 180 residents.A record was made of 136 species of wild food plants and 22 species of edible mushrooms gathered in the area. The most frequently collected species are Rubus ulmifolius Schott, Cornus mas L., Portulaca oleracea L., Asparagus acutifolius L., Sonchus spp., Morus spp., Taraxacum spp., Amaranthus retroflexus L., Cichorium intybus L., and Dioscorea communis (L.) Caddick & Wilkin. RESULTS A record was made of 136 species of wild food plants and 22 species of edible mushrooms gathered in the area. The most frequently collected species are Rubus ulmifolius Schott, Cornus mas L., Portulaca oleracea L., Asparagus acutifolius L., Sonchus spp., Morus spp., Taraxacum spp., Amaranthus retroflexus L., Cichorium intybus L., and Dioscorea communis (L.) Caddick & Wilkin.The list of taxa used is typical for other (sub-)Mediterranean parts of Croatia; however, more fungi species are used. The most important finding of the paper is probably the recording of Legousia speculum-veneris (L.) Chaix, a wild vegetable used in the area. CONCLUSIONS The list of taxa used is typical for other (sub-)Mediterranean parts of Croatia; however, more fungi species are used. The most important finding of the paper is probably the recording of Legousia speculum-veneris (L.) Chaix, a wild vegetable used in the area.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tonka&amp;aulast=Nin%C4%8Devi%C4%87+Runji%C4%87&amp;atitle=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;stitle=Plants+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fplants13081079&amp;title=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Tonka&amp;aulast=Nin%C4%8Devi%C4%87+Runji%C4%87&amp;atitle=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;stitle=Plants+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fplants13081079&amp;title=Wild+Edible+Plants+Used+in+Dalmatian+Zagora+%28Croatia%29&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Effects of a serious smartphone game on nursing students' theoretical knowledge and practical skills in adult basic life support: Randomized wait list–controlled trial

Author: Fijačko, Nino1; Creber, Ruth Masterson2; Metličar, Špela1    ; Strnad, Matej3    ; Greif, Robert4    ; Štiglic, Gregor1    ; Skok, Pavel31 Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Maribor, Maribor, Slovenia nino.fijacko@um.si2 School of Nursing, Columbia University, New York, NY, US3 Maribor University, Medical Centre, Maribor, Slovenia4 European Resuscitation Council Research Net, Niels, Belgium

Publication info: Fijačko, Nino; Creber, Ruth Masterson; Metličar, Špela; Strnad, Matej; Greif, Robert; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effects-serious-smartphone-game-on-nursing/docview/3192359536/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: Retention of adult basic life support (BLS) knowledge and skills after professional training declines over time. To combat this, the European Resuscitation Council and the American Heart Association recommend shorter, more frequent BLS sessions. Emphasizing technology-enhanced learning, such as mobile learning, aims to increase out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) survival and is becoming more integral in nursing education. Objective: The aim of this study was to investigate whether playing a serious smartphone game called MOBICPR at home can improve and retain nursing students’ theoretical knowledge of and practical skills in adult BLS. Methods: This study used a randomized wait list–controlled design. Nursing students were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to either a MOBICPR intervention group (MOBICPR-IG) or a wait-list control group (WL-CG), where the latter received the MOBICPR game 2 weeks after the MOBICPR-IG. The aim of the MOBICPR game is to engage participants in using smartphone gestures (eg, tapping) and actions (eg, talking) to perform evidence-based adult BLS on a virtual patient with OHCA. The participants’ theoretical knowledge of adult BLS was assessed using a questionnaire, while their practical skills were evaluated on cardiopulmonary resuscitation quality parameters using a manikin and a checklist. Results: In total, 43 nursing students participated in the study, 22 (51%) in MOBICPR-IG and 21 (49%) in WL-CG. There were differences between the MOBICPR-IG and the WL-CG in theoretical knowledge ( P = .04) but not in practical skills ( P = .45) after MOBICPR game playing at home. No difference was noted in the retention of participants’ theoretical knowledge and practical skills of adult BLS after a 2-week break from playing the MOBICPR game ( P = .13). Key observations included challenges in response checks with a face-down manikin and a general neglect of safety protocols when using an automated external defibrillator. Conclusions: Playing the MOBICPR game at home has the greatest impact on improving the theoretical knowledge of adult BLS in nursing students but not their practical skills. Our findings underscore the importance of integrating diverse scenarios into adult BLS training. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2025 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Nino&amp;aulast=Fija%C4%8Dko&amp;atitle=Effects+of+a+serious+smartphone+game+on+nursing+students%27+theoretical+knowledge+and+practical+skills+in+adult+basic+life+support%3A+Randomized+wait+list%26ndash%3Bcontrolled+trial&amp;stitle=JMIR+Serious+Games&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.2196%2F56037&amp;title=Effects+of+a+serious+smartphone+game+on+nursing+students%27+theoretical+knowledge+and+practical+skills+in+adult+basic+life+support%3A+Randomized+wait+list%E2%80%93controlled+trial&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=e56037&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Nino&amp;aulast=Fija%C4%8Dko&amp;atitle=Effects+of+a+serious+smartphone+game+on+nursing+students%27+theoretical+knowledge+and+practical+skills+in+adult+basic+life+support%3A+Randomized+wait+list%26ndash%3Bcontrolled+trial&amp;stitle=JMIR+Serious+Games&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.2196%2F56037&amp;title=Effects+of+a+serious+smartphone+game+on+nursing+students%27+theoretical+knowledge+and+practical+skills+in+adult+basic+life+support%3A+Randomized+wait+list%E2%80%93controlled+trial&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=e56037&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Effect of extended precision nursing on neurobehavioral function and pregnancy outcome in patients with threatened abortion

Author: Shen, Lijun1; Wei, Chunqing; Wu, Yalian; Wu, Yayuan; Zheng, Ying    1 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Huanggang Central Hospital Huanggang, Hubei 438000, China

Publication info: Shen, Lijun; Wei, Chunqing; Wu, Yalian; Wu, Yayuan; Zheng, Ying. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effect-extended-precision-nursing-on/docview/3034242335/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study aimed to assess the impact of continuous precision nursing on neurobehavioral function and pregnancy outcomes in patients experiencing threatened abortion. A total of 130 patients with early threatened abortion admitted to our hospital between October 2020 and January 2023 were selected and categorized into 2 groups based on intervention methods. The control group received routine nursing intervention, whereas the observation group received continuous precision nursing intervention. Changes in affective status scores, SF-36 scores, knowledge mastery scores, and satisfaction scores in the neurobehavioral function test before and after intervention were recorded in both groups. Additionally, pregnancy outcomes, obstetric adverse reaction rates, and neonatal conditions were documented. Following intervention, scores for tension-anxiety, depression-dejection, anger-hostility, vigor-activity, fatigue-inertia, and confusion-bewilderment gradually decreased in both groups, with significantly lower scores observed in the observation group compared to the control group (P   .05). Continuous precision nursing contributes to improved pregnancy outcomes for patients with threatened miscarriage within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. This comprehensive care approach is associated with enhanced knowledge retention, protection of neurological function, and an overall improvement in quality of life.This study aimed to assess the impact of continuous precision nursing on neurobehavioral function and pregnancy outcomes in patients experiencing threatened abortion. A total of 130 patients with early threatened abortion admitted to our hospital between October 2020 and January 2023 were selected and categorized into 2 groups based on intervention methods. The control group received routine nursing intervention, whereas the observation group received continuous precision nursing intervention. Changes in affective status scores, SF-36 scores, knowledge mastery scores, and satisfaction scores in the neurobehavioral function test before and after intervention were recorded in both groups. Additionally, pregnancy outcomes, obstetric adverse reaction rates, and neonatal conditions were documented. Following intervention, scores for tension-anxiety, depression-dejection, anger-hostility, vigor-activity, fatigue-inertia, and confusion-bewilderment gradually decreased in both groups, with significantly lower scores observed in the observation group compared to the control group (P   .05). Continuous precision nursing contributes to improved pregnancy outcomes for patients with threatened miscarriage within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. This comprehensive care approach is associated with enhanced knowledge retention, protection of neurological function, and an overall improvement in quality of life.

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Lijun&amp;aulast=Shen&amp;atitle=Effect+of+extended+precision+nursing+on+neurobehavioral+function+and+pregnancy+outcome+in+patients+with+threatened+abortion&amp;stitle=Medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1097%2FMD.0000000000037133&amp;title=Effect+of+extended+precision+nursing+on+neurobehavioral+function+and+pregnancy+outcome+in+patients+with+threatened+abortion&amp;volume=103&amp;issue=14&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=e37133&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

IJCM_127A: A comparative study of knowledge and perception among school going adolescents regarding various food habits and prevalence of overweight and obesity in government and private schools in Mangalore

Author: Jain, Rishabh1; Rajesh, Major SM1; Renganathan, Gayathri11 Kasturba Medical College, Mangalore, Manipal Academy of Higher Education, Manipal, India

Publication info: Jain, Rishabh; Rajesh, Major SM; Renganathan, Gayathri. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/ijcm-127a-comparative-study-knowledge-perception/docview/3280342403/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: Adolescence, 10-19 years is a vulnerable age where eating behaviours are inculcated. Adult health and size are determined by the adolescents dietary habits. The poor health & diet choices by adolescents is a result of lack of knowledge about Glycemic Index, Trans Fats, etc. Thus, educating them at this mouldable age is important. Objectives: 1) To study the knowledge and its retention among adolescents of 8th-12th standard after interactive education about food habits and lifestyle changes. 2) To identify the prevalence of overweight and obesity among high school students in various private and government schools. Methodology: An intervention study was conducted in 441 adolescents of 8th- 12th standard in government and private schools. In first interaction BMI and questionnaire on awareness, perception and practise on diet was filled by participants and educational material on same was shared and their knowledge retention was assessed after 2 months and the results were compared between government and private schools. Results: In terms of age, the majority of subjects fall into the 14-year-old category (37.3%), and 15-year-old (33.2%). In terms of class, the largest proportion is in 9th and 10th class (36.4%). Gender distribution shows majority of females (57.5%). Father’s educational status reveals a significant percentage of graduates (48.4%), while mothers have a high school education (59.3%). Majority follow a non-vegetarian diet (64.3%) and reside in urban areas (54.8%). Lastly, the distribution of BMI categories indicates that a significant portion falls within the normal range (48.2%), with rest as overweight (30.2%), obese (20.7%), and underweight (0.9%). Mean scores of pre and post intervention were compared and statistically significant difference (p=<0.001) was noted. Conclusion: Adolescents are at higher risk of overweight and obesity. Nutritional education reinforcement in this period has significant impact on reduction of Non-Communicable Diseases. Knowledge intervention in this study had similar result.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Rishabh&amp;aulast=Jain&amp;atitle=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;stitle=Indian+Journal+of+Community+Medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fijcm.ijcm_abstract127&amp;title=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=Suppl+1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=S37&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Rishabh&amp;aulast=Jain&amp;atitle=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;stitle=Indian+Journal+of+Community+Medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fijcm.ijcm_abstract127&amp;title=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=Suppl+1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=S37&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Overweight; Diet; Private schools; Education; Teenagers; Obesity

Title: IJCM_127A: A comparative study of knowledge and perception among school going adolescents regarding various food habits and prevalence of overweight and obesity in government and private schools in Mangalore

____________________________________________________________

Co-design and development of the sit-stand e -guide: An e -training program for the optimal use of sit-stand workstations

Author: Zergui ne, Haroun1    ; Healy, Genevieve N.2    ; Goode, Ana D.2    ; Abbott, Alison3; Johnston, Venerina11 University of Queensland, School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences, Brisbane, QLD, Australia h.zerguine@uq.edu.au2 University of Queensland, School of Human Movement and Nutrition Sciences, Brisbane, QLD, Australia3 Office of Industrial Relations, Queensland Government, Brisbane, QLD, Australia

Publication info: Zerguine, Haroun; Healy, Genevieve N; Goode, Ana D; Abbott, Alison; Johnston, Venerina. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/co-design-development-sit-stand-i-e-guide/docview/3206589795/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This paper describes the co-design and development process of an evidence-informed e -training program (Sit-Stand e -Guide) to support the safe and optimal use of sit-stand workstations from ergonomics and behavioural change perspectives. Using an instructional system design process, supported by a participatory design approach, data was collected through three workshops with workplace consumers (staff [n = 5] and managers [n = 5]), and subject matter experts (n = 5). Content and learning activities were developed based on behaviour change principles and optimal pedagogy. Key topics identified for the e -training were sedentary behaviour and health; workstation set-up; and strategies for behaviour change. Learning activities (scenarios and reflection) to enhance knowledge retention and skills implementation and an interactive one-page guide on completion were included in the e -training. The relevance and usefulness of the training prototype were reviewed through one-to-one think-aloud sessions with the workshop consumers (n = 5) and external health and safety professionals (n = 5) receiving positive feedback. The Sit-Stand e -Guide is readily available for workplace implementation and evaluation. This paper serves as a practical guide for future training development. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2025 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Haroun&amp;aulast=Zerguine&amp;atitle=Co-design+and+development+of+the+sit-stande-guide%3A+Ane-training+program+for+the+optimal+use+of+sit-stand+workstations&amp;stitle=Applied+Ergonomics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.apergo.2023.104207&amp;title=Co-design+and+development+of+the+sit-stande-guide%3A+Ane-training+program+for+the+optimal+use+of+sit-stand+workstations&amp;volume=116&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=104207&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Haroun&amp;aulast=Zerguine&amp;atitle=Co-design+and+development+of+the+sit-stande-guide%3A+Ane-training+program+for+the+optimal+use+of+sit-stand+workstations&amp;stitle=Applied+Ergonomics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.apergo.2023.104207&amp;title=Co-design+and+development+of+the+sit-stande-guide%3A+Ane-training+program+for+the+optimal+use+of+sit-stand+workstations&amp;volume=116&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=104207&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Análisis de los factores que influyen en el desaprendizaje organizacional: Revisión integrativa

Author: Ríos-Zaruma, Julio1; Caguana, Dayanara2; Varvakis, Gregorio31 Universidad Técnica Particular de Loja, 1101608 Loja, Ecuador/Programa de Pôs-Graduaçâo em Engenharia e Gestǎo do Conhecimento, Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina, 88040-900, Florianópolis, Santa Catarina, Brasil2 Departamento de Ciencias Empresariales, Universidad Técnica Particular de Loja, 1101608, Loja, Ecuador3 Programa de Pôs-Graduaçâo em Engenharia e Gestǎo do Conhecimento, Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina, 88040-900, Florianópolis, Santa Catarina, Brasil

Publication info: Ríos-Zaruma, Julio; Caguana, Dayanara; Varvakis, Gregorio. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/análisis-de-los-factores-que-influyen-en-el/docview/3182407115/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Abstract: This article identified the factors related to unlearning in organizations at the individual, group, and organizational levels. Data collection was carried out in the Web of Science, Scopus, and Scielo databases. The most used facilitators were reflective capacity, turbulence, and knowledge management. Los términos utilizados fueron: unlearn, forget, knowledge loss, knowledge depreciation, unlearn context, organizational unlearn, organizational performance, firm performance, olvidar, pérdida de conocimiento, depreciación de conocimiento, desaprendizaje, contexto de desaprendizaje, desaprendizaje organizaciona!, desempeño organizaciona!, desempeño de la firma y desempeño.

Markets and Metis: Reading Hayek with Scott

Author: Reamer, Robert11 King's College London

Publication info: Reamer, Robert. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/markets-metis-reading-hayek-with-scott/docview/3179260461/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Both James C. Scott and Friedrich Hayek articulate critiques of centralised state planning that are fundamentally epistemological in character. In particular, both emphasize the loss of knowledge resulting from attempts to achieve synoptic legibility of complex social practices. Yet while Hayek's critique of central planning leads to an emphasis on the indispensability of the price system, Scott argues that capitalist markets are also mechanisms of perverse simplification. This paper explores the roots of this disagreement and seeks to articulate the insights that emerge from reading Hayek and Scott together on questions of markets, knowledge, and the state.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Robert&amp;aulast=Reamer&amp;atitle=Markets+and+Metis%3A+Reading+Hayek+with+Scott&amp;stitle=Critical+Review&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F08913811.2024.2354648&amp;title=Markets+and+Metis%3A+Reading+Hayek+with+Scott&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=162&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Robert&amp;aulast=Reamer&amp;atitle=Markets+and+Metis%3A+Reading+Hayek+with+Scott&amp;stitle=Critical+Review&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F08913811.2024.2354648&amp;title=Markets+and+Metis%3A+Reading+Hayek+with+Scott&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=162&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Virtual Dissection Table Case Studies for Undergraduate Neuroanatomy Written Assignments

Author: Wang, Joshua1; Beecher, Kate2; Chehrehasa, Fatemeh31 School of Clinical Sciences, Faculty of Health, Queensland University of Technology, 2 George Street, Brisbane 4000 QLD, Australia2 UQ Centre for Clinical Research, Faculty of Medicine, University of Queensland, Building 71/918 Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital Campus, Herston 4029, QLD, Australia3 School of Biomedical Sciences, Faculty of Health, Queensland University of Technology, 2 George Street, Brisbane 4000 QLD, Australia

Publication info: Wang, Joshua; Beecher, Kate; Chehrehasa, Fatemeh. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/virtual-dissection-table-case-studies/docview/3112116557/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Neuroanatomy education benefits from cadaveric specimens, yet challenges with access, cost, and health concerns exist. Virtual Dissection Tables (VDTs) offer digital alternatives to traditional cadaveric learning. This article evaluates the pedagogical value of VDTs in undergraduate neuroanatomy education. While VDTs, primarily Anatomage, offer interactive 3D cadaveric images and customization options, research on their impact on neuroanatomy learning outcomes remain limited. Existing studies suggest comparable knowledge retention between VDTs and cadaveric learning, with varying effects on student satisfaction. Investigations of non-exam-based neuroanatomy assessments, however, are scarce. This study presents a case study using VDTs as the basis for a neuroscience assignment report, exploring its construction, and evaluating its strengths, and weaknesses through a student survey. Implemented in an advanced neuroscience course, the assignment involves analyzing 3D reconstructed MRI scans of neuropathological conditions displayed on the VDT. The task requires students to collate, analyze, and predict symptoms based on the pathology observed, aligning their findings with neuroscience literature. This innovative approach aims to enhance research and academic writing skills while expanding the use of VDTs beyond traditional assessment formats in neuroscience education. We found that the case-study format benefited students' neuroanatomy learning and application ability. Further studies should be conducted, however, to understand the effect of VDT use on learning outcomes in case study contexts.Neuroanatomy education benefits from cadaveric specimens, yet challenges with access, cost, and health concerns exist. Virtual Dissection Tables (VDTs) offer digital alternatives to traditional cadaveric learning. This article evaluates the pedagogical value of VDTs in undergraduate neuroanatomy education. While VDTs, primarily Anatomage, offer interactive 3D cadaveric images and customization options, research on their impact on neuroanatomy learning outcomes remain limited. Existing studies suggest comparable knowledge retention between VDTs and cadaveric learning, with varying effects on student satisfaction. Investigations of non-exam-based neuroanatomy assessments, however, are scarce. This study presents a case study using VDTs as the basis for a neuroscience assignment report, exploring its construction, and evaluating its strengths, and weaknesses through a student survey. Implemented in an advanced neuroscience course, the assignment involves analyzing 3D reconstructed MRI scans of neuropathological conditions displayed on the VDT. The task requires students to collate, analyze, and predict symptoms based on the pathology observed, aligning their findings with neuroscience literature. This innovative approach aims to enhance research and academic writing skills while expanding the use of VDTs beyond traditional assessment formats in neuroscience education. We found that the case-study format benefited students' neuroanatomy learning and application ability. Further studies should be conducted, however, to understand the effect of VDT use on learning outcomes in case study contexts.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Joshua&amp;aulast=Wang&amp;atitle=Virtual+Dissection+Table+Case+Studies+for+Undergraduate+Neuroanatomy+Written+Assignments&amp;stitle=Journal+of+undergraduate+neuroscience+education+%3A+JUNE+%3A+a+publication+of+FUN%2C+Faculty+for+Undergraduate+Neuroscience&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.59390%2FJDOG5046&amp;title=Virtual+Dissection+Table+Case+Studies+for+Undergraduate+Neuroanatomy+Written+Assignments&amp;volume=22&amp;issue=3&amp;date=Spring+2024&amp;spage=A256&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Joshua&amp;aulast=Wang&amp;atitle=Virtual+Dissection+Table+Case+Studies+for+Undergraduate+Neuroanatomy+Written+Assignments&amp;stitle=Journal+of+undergraduate+neuroscience+education+%3A+JUNE+%3A+a+publication+of+FUN%2C+Faculty+for+Undergraduate+Neuroscience&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.59390%2FJDOG5046&amp;title=Virtual+Dissection+Table+Case+Studies+for+Undergraduate+Neuroanatomy+Written+Assignments&amp;volume=22&amp;issue=3&amp;date=Spring+2024&amp;spage=A256&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

IJCM_127A: A comparative study of knowledge and perception among school going adolescents regarding various food habits and prevalence of overweight and obesity in government and private schools in Mangalore

Author: Jain Rishabh; Rajesh Major SM; Renganathan Gayathri

Publication info: Jain Rishabh; Rajesh Major SM; Renganathan Gayathri. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/ijcm-127a-comparative-study-knowledge-perception/docview/3111498732/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: Adolescence, 10-19 years is a vulnerable age where eating behaviours are inculcated. Adult health and size are determined by the adolescents dietary habits. The poor health & diet choices by adolescents is a result of lack of knowledge about Glycemic Index, Trans Fats, etc. Thus, educating them at this mouldable age is important. Objectives: 1) To study the knowledge and its retention among adolescents of 8th-12th standard after interactive education about food habits and lifestyle changes. 2) To identify the prevalence of overweight and obesity among high school students in various private and government schools. Methodology: An intervention study was conducted in 441 adolescents of 8th- 12th standard in government and private schools. In first interaction BMI and questionnaire on awareness, perception and practise on diet was filled by participants and educational material on same was shared and their knowledge retention was assessed after 2 months and the results were compared between government and private schools. Results: In terms of age, the majority of subjects fall into the 14-year-old category (37.3%), and 15-year-old (33.2%). In terms of class, the largest proportion is in 9th and 10th class (36.4%). Gender distribution shows majority of females (57.5%). Father’s educational status reveals a significant percentage of graduates (48.4%), while mothers have a high school education (59.3%). Majority follow a non-vegetarian diet (64.3%) and reside in urban areas (54.8%). Lastly, the distribution of BMI categories indicates that a significant portion falls within the normal range (48.2%), with rest as overweight (30.2%), obese (20.7%), and underweight (0.9%). Mean scores of pre and post intervention were compared and statistically significant difference (p=<0.001) was noted. Conclusion: Adolescents are at higher risk of overweight and obesity. Nutritional education reinforcement in this period has significant impact on reduction of Non-Communicable Diseases. Knowledge intervention in this study had similar result.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Jain+Rishabh&amp;atitle=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;stitle=Indian+Journal+of+Community+Medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fijcm.ijcm_abstract127&amp;title=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=Suppl+1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=S37&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Jain+Rishabh&amp;atitle=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;stitle=Indian+Journal+of+Community+Medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fijcm.ijcm_abstract127&amp;title=IJCM_127A%3A+A+comparative+study+of+knowledge+and+perception+among+school+going+adolescents+regarding+various+food+habits+and+prevalence+of+overweight+and+obesity+in+government+and+private+schools+in+Mangalore&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=Suppl+1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=S37&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;
