____________________________________________________________

Effect of Dental Practicality Index training using an online video on decision-making and confidence level in treatment planning by dental undergraduates

Author: See, Zhai Wei1    ; Lee, Ming Sern1    ; Parolia, Abhishek2    ; Kanagasingam, Shalini3    ; Gunjal, Shilpa1    ; Patel, Shanon4    1 School of Dentistry, International Medical University, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia2 School of Dentistry, International Medical University, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Department of Endodontics, University of Iowa College of Dentistry and Dental Clinics, Iowa City, IA, USA3 School of Dentistry, Faculty of Clinical and Biomedical Sciences, University of Central Lancashire, Preston, United Kingdom4 Department of Endodontology, King's College London Dental Institute, London, United Kingdom

Publication info: See, Zhai Wei; Lee, Ming Sern; Parolia, Abhishek; Kanagasingam, Shalini; Gunjal, Shilpa; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/effect-dental-practicality-index-training-using/docview/2942190376/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of Dental Practicality Index (DPI) training using an online video on the treatment planning decisions and confidence level of dental undergraduates (DUs). Objectives The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of Dental Practicality Index (DPI) training using an online video on the treatment planning decisions and confidence level of dental undergraduates (DUs).Ninety-four DUs were shown 15 clinical case scenarios and asked to decide on treatment plans based on 4 treatment options. The most appropriate treatment plan had been decided by a consensus panel of experienced dentists. DUs then underwent DPI training using an online video. In a post-DPI-training test, DUs were shown the same clinical case scenarios and asked to assign the best treatment option. After 6 weeks, DUs were retested to assess their knowledge retention. In all 3 tests, DUs completed the confidence level scale questionnaire. Data were analyzed using the related-samples Wilcoxon signed rank test and the independent-samples Mann-Whitney U test with the level of significance set at p < 0.05. Materials and Methods Ninety-four DUs were shown 15 clinical case scenarios and asked to decide on treatment plans based on 4 treatment options. The most appropriate treatment plan had been decided by a consensus panel of experienced dentists. DUs then underwent DPI training using an online video. In a post-DPI-training test, DUs were shown the same clinical case scenarios and asked to assign the best treatment option. After 6 weeks, DUs were retested to assess their knowledge retention. In all 3 tests, DUs completed the confidence level scale questionnaire. Data were analyzed using the related-samples Wilcoxon signed rank test and the independent-samples Mann-Whitney U test with the level of significance set at p < 0.05.DPI training significantly improved the mean scores of the DUs from 7.53 in the pre-DPI-training test to 9.01 in the post-DPI-training test ( p < 0.001). After 6 weeks, the mean scores decreased marginally to 8.87 in the retention test ( p = 0.563). DPI training increased their confidence level from 5.68 pre-DPI training to 7.09 post-DPI training. Results DPI training significantly improved the mean scores of the DUs from 7.53 in the pre-DPI-training test to 9.01 in the post-DPI-training test (p < 0.001). After 6 weeks, the mean scores decreased marginally to 8.87 in the retention test (p = 0.563). DPI training increased their confidence level from 5.68 pre-DPI training to 7.09 post-DPI training.Training DUs using DPI with an online video improved their decision-making and confidence level in treatment planning. Conclusions Training DUs using DPI with an online video improved their decision-making and confidence level in treatment planning.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zhai&amp;aulast=See&amp;atitle=Effect+of+Dental+Practicality+Index+training+using+an+online+video+on+decision-making+and+confidence+level+in+treatment+planning+by+dental+undergraduates&amp;stitle=Restorative+dentistry+%26+endodontics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.5395%2Frde.2024.49.e8&amp;title=Effect+of+Dental+Practicality+Index+training+using+an+online+video+on+decision-making+and+confidence+level+in+treatment+planning+by+dental+undergraduates&amp;volume=49&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=e8&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Undergraduate nursing students’ learning experiences using design thinking on a human development course: A phenomenological study

Author: Yao, YuChun1; Long, Ann2; Tseng, Yun Shan3; Chun-Ying, Chiang1; Fan-Ko, Sun41 Department of Nursing, I-Shou University,   No.8, Yida Rd., Jiaosu Village, Yanchao District,   Kaohsiung City 82445,   Taiwan, ROC2 Honorary Fellow of Ulster University, School of Nursing, Ulster University, 41. North Parade, Ormeau Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland BT 72GH, UK3 Department of Nursing, I-Shou University, No.8, Yida Rd., Jiaosu Village, Yanchao District, Kaohsiung City 82445, Taiwan, ROC4 Second Degree Bachelor of Science in Nursing, National Taiwan University, No.1 Jen Ai road section 1 Taipei 100 Taiwan, ROC; Department of Nursing, National Taiwan University Hospital Yunlin Branch, Taiwan, ROC

Publication info: Yao, YuChun; Long, Ann; Tseng, Yun Shan; Chun-Ying, Chiang; Fan-Ko, Sun. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/undergraduate-nursing-students-learning/docview/2927844661/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Aim To explore nursing students’ perceptions of their design thinking learning experiences on a human development course. Background Design thinking is a person-centered analytic and creative learning process that promotes higher order thinking skills rather than knowledge retention alone. Currently, this is the first study that has investigated the use of the design thinking process for nursing students on a human development course. Design A phenomenological research design. Methods The participants were first-year nursing students enrolled on a human development course at a Taiwanese university. In-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted in 2022 and sufficiently high information power was obtained after 15 participants were interviewed. Data were systematically analysed, summarized and decoded using Colaizzi’s seven analysis steps. Results Three themes and twelve subthemes emerged from the data. (1) Challenges experienced with the design thinking learning process: participants experienced anxiety because of the unfamiliar assignments, and they found the assignments to be thought-consuming, time-consuming and energy-consuming, plus the students needed to adapt to working in teams with classmates. (2) Adjustment strategies employed by participants: participants highlighted the importance of teamwork during the design thinking learning process. They achieved consensus through communication and sought support from others to overcome challenges related to design thinking; however, they ultimately needed to engage in problem-solving by themselves. (3) Developing the diversity of academic capabilities: after the human development course, participants experienced enriched mindsets, cognitive abilities, problem-solving skills, interpersonal relationships and knowledge application. Conclusions Design thinking provides creative teaching opportunities and encourages nursing students to engage in experimental and creative learning, which is a meaningful experience for them. Nurse educators could use the insights thus obtained to design a curriculum that sources design thinking as a learning process while facilitating the complexity and diversity of students’ higher order thinking skills and not just repetitive learning.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=YuChun&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=Undergraduate+nursing+students%26rsquo%3B+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;stitle=Nurse+Education+in+Practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103886&amp;title=Undergraduate+nursing+students%E2%80%99+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103886&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=YuChun&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=Undergraduate+nursing+students%26rsquo%3B+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;stitle=Nurse+Education+in+Practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103886&amp;title=Undergraduate+nursing+students%E2%80%99+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103886&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Child development; Students; Nursing education; Phenomenology; Teaching methods; Problem solving; Human development; Nursing; Cognitive ability; Thinking skills; Interviews; Cognition & reasoning; Consent; Sample size; Design thinking; Learning; College students; Interpersonal relations; Teaching; Data collection; Empathy; Nurse tutors; Metacognition; Consciousness; Higher order thinking skills; Curricula; Patient-centered care; Perceptions; Cognitive development; Research design; Creativity; Anxiety; Cognition; Teamwork; Nurses; Teachers; Skills; Curriculum development

Title: Undergraduate nursing students’ learning experiences using design thinking on a human development course: A phenomenological study

Enhancing delirium assessment and management through nursing education interventions: A scoping review

Author: Zhao, Yunchuan1; Missbrenner, Nicolette1; Xu, H Daniel2; Josephson, Jayne11 School of Nursing, Boise State University,   1910 University Drive, Mail Stop 1840,   Boise,   ID 83725,   United States2 Department of Political Science, East Carolina University,   1000 E 5th Street, Mail Stop 564,   Greenville,   NC 27858,   United States

Publication info: Zhao, Yunchuan; Missbrenner, Nicolette; Xu, H Daniel; Josephson, Jayne. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/enhancing-delirium-assessment-management-through/docview/2927844645/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Aim/objective The purpose of this scoping review was to explore the characteristics and outcomes of education interventions for nurses focused on delirium assessment and management. Background Delirium is a prevalent acute and reversible neuropsychiatric syndrome in hospitalized patients. Delirium can cause cognitive, psychiatric and physical impairments and result in prolonged hospital stay, increased risk of readmission and elevated morbidity and mortality rates. Nurses play an essential role in managing delirium. There is a lack of understanding of the existing nursing educational interventions on delirium management. Design The study was a scoping review. Methods In this scoping review, we used Arksey and O'Malley's (2005) scoping review framework. We searched articles published between 2019 and 2023 in Academic Search Premier, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) and MEDLINE using the following CINAHL/MeSH suggested subject terms: “delirium” in conjunction with “education” “intervention” and “nurse”, “nurses” or “nursing.” Studies on improving nursing knowledge and practices regarding delirium were included while those focusing on nursing students were excluded. Initial screening involved evaluating article titles and abstracts for relevance from 164 identified articles, followed by a full-text review of 42 articles. Finally, 17 articles were selected for comprehensive analysis. We extracted relevant information from each article and charted the findings in an evidence table. Results The 17 selected articles showcased a variety of interventions used to educate nursing staff, such as workshops, simulations, group discussions, online modules and one-on-one coaching. Educational interventions primarily focused on delirium definition, risk factors, assessment and management. These educational interventions enhanced nurses' perception of delirium, boosting their confidence and knowledge in managing delirium. These interventions also led to increased compliance with delirium assessment and management protocols, which ultimately resulted in improved documentation accuracy and patient outcomes. Conclusions Findings from this scoping review suggest that nursing administration need to provide support and education for delirium prevention and management to enhance nursing staff confidence and competence in assessing and managing delirium. The use of interactive educational techniques has demonstrated profound benefits in schema development, expertize promotion and critical thinking. These findings have significant implications for future research, including the identification of essential nursing competencies for educational interventions and the assessment of long-term knowledge retention and its application in nursing practice.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yunchuan&amp;aulast=Zhao&amp;atitle=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;stitle=Nurse+Education+in+Practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103887&amp;title=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103887&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yunchuan&amp;aulast=Zhao&amp;atitle=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;stitle=Nurse+Education+in+Practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103887&amp;title=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103887&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Research; Intervention; Hospitalized; Morbidity; Risk factors; Coaching; Health promotion; Mortality; Evaluation; Risk assessment; Professional identity; Delirium; Nursing; Electronic publishing; Competence; Workshops; Nurses; Reversible; Clinical outcomes; Medical education; Patients; Professional practice; Physical disabilities; Readmission; Knowledge; Nursing care; Medical screening; Evidence-based nursing; Mortality rates; Geriatrics; Medical records; Intensive care; Systematic review; Education; Critical thinking; Nursing education; Management; Psychiatry; Hospitalization; Medical personnel; Documentation; Risk management; Mental health services; Learning outcomes

Title: Enhancing delirium assessment and management through nursing education interventions: A scoping review

Publication title: Nurse Education in Practice; Kidlington

First available: 2024-02-17

Updates: 2024-02-17; 2024-02-19; 2024-02-19; 2024-03-09; 2024-03-27; 2024-04-10; 2024-04-16; 2024-08-27; 2025-11-08

A domain adaptation method for bearing fault diagnosis using multiple incomplete source data

Author: Wang, Qibin1; Xu, Yuanbing1; Yang, Shengkang1; Chang, Jiantao1    ; Zhang, Jingang1; Kong, Xianguang11 Xidian University, School of Mechano-Electronic Engineering, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China (GRID:grid.440736.2) (ISNI:0000 0001 0707 115X)

Publication info: Wang, Qibin; Xu, Yuanbing; Yang, Shengkang; Chang, Jiantao; Zhang, Jingang; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/domain-adaptation-method-bearing-fault-diagnosis/docview/2921419952/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The fault diagnosis method based on domain adaptation is a hot topic in recent years. It is difficult to collect a complete data set containing all fault categories in practice under the same working condition, leading to fault categories knowledge loss in the single source domain. To resolve the problem, a domain adaptation method for bearing fault diagnosis using multiple incomplete source data is proposed in this study. First, the cycle generative adversarial network is used to learn the mapping between multi-source domains to complement the missing category data. Then, considering the domain mismatch problem, a multi-source domain adaption model based on anchor adapters is developed to obtain general domain invariant diagnosis knowledge. Finally, the fault diagnosis model is established by an ensemble of multi-classifier results. Extensive experiments on bearing data sets demonstrate that the proposed method in fault diagnosis with multiple incomplete source data is effective and has a good diagnosis performance.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Qibin&amp;aulast=Wang&amp;atitle=A+domain+adaptation+method+for+bearing+fault+diagnosis+using+multiple+incomplete+source+data&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Intelligent+Manufacturing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs10845-023-02075-7&amp;title=A+domain+adaptation+method+for+bearing+fault+diagnosis+using+multiple+incomplete+source+data&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=777&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Qibin&amp;aulast=Wang&amp;atitle=A+domain+adaptation+method+for+bearing+fault+diagnosis+using+multiple+incomplete+source+data&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Intelligent+Manufacturing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs10845-023-02075-7&amp;title=A+domain+adaptation+method+for+bearing+fault+diagnosis+using+multiple+incomplete+source+data&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=777&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Buckle me up! A randomised controlled trial using a tablet-based emergency department intervention for child car safety education

Author: Angela Yu Zhang1    ; Leviter, Julie2; Baird, Janette3; Charles-Chauvet, Danielle4; Frackiewicz, Laura M5    ; Duffy, Susan6; Almaz Dessie61 Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, USA; Department of Pediatrics, University of Washington School of Medicine, Seattle, Washington, USA2 Department of Emergency Medicine, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, USA; Department of Pediatrics, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, USA3 Department of Emergency Medicine, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, USA; Injury Prevention Center, Rhode Island Hospital, Providence, Rhode Island, USA4 Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, USA; Department of Emergency Medicine, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Mount Sinai, New York, USA5 Providence College, Providence, Rhode Island, USA; University of New England College of Osteopathic Medicine, Biddeford, Maine, USA6 Department of Emergency Medicine, Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, USA

Publication info: Angela Yu Zhang; Leviter, Julie; Baird, Janette; Charles-Chauvet, Danielle; Frackiewicz, Laura M; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/buckle-me-up-randomised-controlled-trial-using/docview/2920660792/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background and objectives Correct child car restraint use significantly reduces risk of death and serious injury in motor vehicle crashes, but millions of US children ride with improper restraints. We created a tablet-based car restraint educational intervention using Computer Intervention Authoring Software (CIAS) and examined its impact on knowledge and behaviours among parents in the paediatric emergency department (PED). Methods This was a non-blinded, randomised controlled trial of parents of PED patients ages 0–12 years. Participants were evaluated for baseline car restraint knowledge and behaviour. The intervention group completed an interactive tablet-based module, while the control group received printed handouts on car restraint safety. After 1 week, both groups received a follow-up survey assessing changes in car restraint knowledge and behaviour. Logistic regressions determined predictors of knowledge retention and behavioural changes. Parents in the CIAS group were also surveyed on programme acceptability. Results 211 parents completed the study with follow-up data. There was no significant difference in baseline car restraint knowledge (74.3% correct in intervention, 61.8% in control, p=0.15), or increase in follow-up restraint knowledge. Significantly more intervention-group caregivers reported modifying their child’s car restraint at follow-up (52.5% vs 31.8%,p=0.003), and 93.7% of them found CIAS helpful in learning to improve car safety. Conclusion Parents had overall high levels of car restraint knowledge. Using CIAS led to positive behavioural changes regarding child car restraint safety, with the vast majority reporting positive attitudes towards CIAS. This novel, interactive, tablet-based tool is a useful PED intervention for behavioural change in parents. Trial registration number NCT03799393 .

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Angela+Yu+Zhang&amp;atitle=Buckle+me+up%21+A+randomised+controlled+trial+using+a+tablet-based+emergency+department+intervention+for+child+car+safety+education&amp;stitle=Injury+Prevention&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1136%2Fip-2023-044998&amp;title=Buckle+me+up%21+A+randomised+controlled+trial+using+a+tablet-based+emergency+department+intervention+for+child+car+safety+education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=ip-2023-044998&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Angela+Yu+Zhang&amp;atitle=Buckle+me+up%21+A+randomised+controlled+trial+using+a+tablet-based+emergency+department+intervention+for+child+car+safety+education&amp;stitle=Injury+Prevention&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1136%2Fip-2023-044998&amp;title=Buckle+me+up%21+A+randomised+controlled+trial+using+a+tablet-based+emergency+department+intervention+for+child+car+safety+education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=ip-2023-044998&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Enhancing delirium assessment and management through nursing education interventions: A scoping review

Author: Zhao, Yunchuan1; Missbrenner, Nicolette1; Xu, H Daniel2; Josephson, Jayne11 School of Nursing, Boise State University,   1910 University Drive, Mail Stop 1840,   Boise,   ID 83725,   United States lucyzhao@boisestate.edu2 Department of Political Science, East Carolina University,   1000 E 5th Street, Mail Stop 564,   Greenville,   NC 27858,   United States

Publication info: Zhao, Yunchuan; Missbrenner, Nicolette; Xu, H Daniel; Josephson, Jayne. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/enhancing-delirium-assessment-management-through/docview/2917552642/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The purpose of this scoping review was to explore the characteristics and outcomes of education interventions for nurses focused on delirium assessment and management. AIM/OBJECTIVE The purpose of this scoping review was to explore the characteristics and outcomes of education interventions for nurses focused on delirium assessment and management.Delirium is a prevalent acute and reversible neuropsychiatric syndrome in hospitalized patients. Delirium can cause cognitive, psychiatric and physical impairments and result in prolonged hospital stay, increased risk of readmission and elevated morbidity and mortality rates. Nurses play an essential role in managing delirium. There is a lack of understanding of the existing nursing educational interventions on delirium management. BACKGROUND Delirium is a prevalent acute and reversible neuropsychiatric syndrome in hospitalized patients. Delirium can cause cognitive, psychiatric and physical impairments and result in prolonged hospital stay, increased risk of readmission and elevated morbidity and mortality rates. Nurses play an essential role in managing delirium. There is a lack of understanding of the existing nursing educational interventions on delirium management.The study was a scoping review. DESIGN The study was a scoping review.In this scoping review, we used Arksey and O'Malley's (2005) scoping review framework. We searched articles published between 2019 and 2023 in Academic Search Premier, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) and MEDLINE using the following CINAHL/MeSH suggested subject terms: "delirium" in conjunction with "education" "intervention" and "nurse", "nurses" or "nursing." Studies on improving nursing knowledge and practices regarding delirium were included while those focusing on nursing students were excluded. Initial screening involved evaluating article titles and abstracts for relevance from 164 identified articles, followed by a full-text review of 42 articles. Finally, 17 articles were selected for comprehensive analysis. We extracted relevant information from each article and charted the findings in an evidence table. METHODS In this scoping review, we used Arksey and O'Malley's (2005) scoping review framework. We searched articles published between 2019 and 2023 in Academic Search Premier, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) and MEDLINE using the following CINAHL/MeSH suggested subject terms: "delirium" in conjunction with "education" "intervention" and "nurse", "nurses" or "nursing." Studies on improving nursing knowledge and practices regarding delirium were included while those focusing on nursing students were excluded. Initial screening involved evaluating article titles and abstracts for relevance from 164 identified articles, followed by a full-text review of 42 articles. Finally, 17 articles were selected for comprehensive analysis. We extracted relevant information from each article and charted the findings in an evidence table.The 17 selected articles showcased a variety of interventions used to educate nursing staff, such as workshops, simulations, group discussions, online modules and one-on-one coaching. Educational interventions primarily focused on delirium definition, risk factors, assessment and management. These educational interventions enhanced nurses' perception of delirium, boosting their confidence and knowledge in managing delirium. These interventions also led to increased compliance with delirium assessment and management protocols, which ultimately resulted in improved documentation accuracy and patient outcomes. RESULTS The 17 selected articles showcased a variety of interventions used to educate nursing staff, such as workshops, simulations, group discussions, online modules and one-on-one coaching. Educational interventions primarily focused on delirium definition, risk factors, assessment and management. These educational interventions enhanced nurses' perception of delirium, boosting their confidence and knowledge in managing delirium. These interventions also led to increased compliance with delirium assessment and management protocols, which ultimately resulted in improved documentation accuracy and patient outcomes.Findings from this scoping review suggest that nursing administration need to provide support and education for delirium prevention and management to enhance nursing staff confidence and competence in assessing and managing delirium. The use of interactive educational techniques has demonstrated profound benefits in schema development, expertize promotion and critical thinking. These findings have significant implications for future research, including the identification of essential nursing competencies for educational interventions and the assessment of long-term knowledge retention and its application in nursing practice. CONCLUSIONS Findings from this scoping review suggest that nursing administration need to provide support and education for delirium prevention and management to enhance nursing staff confidence and competence in assessing and managing delirium. The use of interactive educational techniques has demonstrated profound benefits in schema development, expertize promotion and critical thinking. These findings have significant implications for future research, including the identification of essential nursing competencies for educational interventions and the assessment of long-term knowledge retention and its application in nursing practice.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yunchuan&amp;aulast=Zhao&amp;atitle=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;stitle=Nurse+education+in+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103887&amp;title=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103887&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yunchuan&amp;aulast=Zhao&amp;atitle=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;stitle=Nurse+education+in+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103887&amp;title=Enhancing+delirium+assessment+and+management+through+nursing+education+interventions%3A+A+scoping+review&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103887&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Undergraduate nursing students' learning experiences using design thinking on a human development course: A phenomenological study

Author: Yao, YuChun1; Long, Ann2; Tseng, Yun Shan3; Chiang, Chun-Ying1; Sun, Fan-Ko41 Department of Nursing, I-Shou University,   No.8, Yida Rd., Jiaosu Village, Yanchao District,   Kaohsiung City 82445,   Taiwan, ROC yuyuyao@isu.edu.tw; chunying@isu.edu.tw2 Honorary Fellow of Ulster University, School of Nursing, Ulster University, 41. North Parade, Ormeau Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland BT 72GH, UK drannlong1@hotmail.com3 Department of Nursing, I-Shou University, No.8, Yida Rd., Jiaosu Village, Yanchao District, Kaohsiung City 82445, Taiwan, ROC ytsen01@isu.edu.tw4 Second Degree Bachelor of Science in Nursing, National Taiwan University, No.1 Jen Ai road section 1 Taipei 100 Taiwan, ROC; Department of Nursing, National Taiwan University Hospital Yunlin Branch, Taiwan, ROC sunfanko@ntu.edu.tw

Publication info: Yao, YuChun; Long, Ann; Tseng, Yun Shan; Chiang, Chun-Ying; Sun, Fan-Ko. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/undergraduate-nursing-students-learning/docview/2915987698/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: To explore nursing students' perceptions of their design thinking learning experiences on a human development course. AIM To explore nursing students' perceptions of their design thinking learning experiences on a human development course.Design thinking is a person-centered analytic and creative learning process that promotes higher order thinking skills rather than knowledge retention alone. Currently, this is the first study that has investigated the use of the design thinking process for nursing students on a human development course. BACKGROUND Design thinking is a person-centered analytic and creative learning process that promotes higher order thinking skills rather than knowledge retention alone. Currently, this is the first study that has investigated the use of the design thinking process for nursing students on a human development course.A phenomenological research design. DESIGN A phenomenological research design.The participants were first-year nursing students enrolled on a human development course at a Taiwanese university. In-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted in 2022 and sufficiently high information power was obtained after 15 participants were interviewed. Data were systematically analysed, summarized and decoded using Colaizzi's seven analysis steps. METHODS The participants were first-year nursing students enrolled on a human development course at a Taiwanese university. In-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted in 2022 and sufficiently high information power was obtained after 15 participants were interviewed. Data were systematically analysed, summarized and decoded using Colaizzi's seven analysis steps.Three themes and twelve subthemes emerged from the data. (1) Challenges experienced with the design thinking learning process: participants experienced anxiety because of the unfamiliar assignments, and they found the assignments to be thought-consuming, time-consuming and energy-consuming, plus the students needed to adapt to working in teams with classmates. (2) Adjustment strategies employed by participants: participants highlighted the importance of teamwork during the design thinking learning process. They achieved consensus through communication and sought support from others to overcome challenges related to design thinking; however, they ultimately needed to engage in problem-solving by themselves. (3) Developing the diversity of academic capabilities: after the human development course, participants experienced enriched mindsets, cognitive abilities, problem-solving skills, interpersonal relationships and knowledge application. RESULTS Three themes and twelve subthemes emerged from the data. (1) Challenges experienced with the design thinking learning process: participants experienced anxiety because of the unfamiliar assignments, and they found the assignments to be thought-consuming, time-consuming and energy-consuming, plus the students needed to adapt to working in teams with classmates. (2) Adjustment strategies employed by participants: participants highlighted the importance of teamwork during the design thinking learning process. They achieved consensus through communication and sought support from others to overcome challenges related to design thinking; however, they ultimately needed to engage in problem-solving by themselves. (3) Developing the diversity of academic capabilities: after the human development course, participants experienced enriched mindsets, cognitive abilities, problem-solving skills, interpersonal relationships and knowledge application.Design thinking provides creative teaching opportunities and encourages nursing students to engage in experimental and creative learning, which is a meaningful experience for them. Nurse educators could use the insights thus obtained to design a curriculum that sources design thinking as a learning process while facilitating the complexity and diversity of students' higher order thinking skills and not just repetitive learning. CONCLUSIONS Design thinking provides creative teaching opportunities and encourages nursing students to engage in experimental and creative learning, which is a meaningful experience for them. Nurse educators could use the insights thus obtained to design a curriculum that sources design thinking as a learning process while facilitating the complexity and diversity of students' higher order thinking skills and not just repetitive learning.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=YuChun&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=Undergraduate+nursing+students%27+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;stitle=Nurse+education+in+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103886&amp;title=Undergraduate+nursing+students%27+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103886&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=YuChun&amp;aulast=Yao&amp;atitle=Undergraduate+nursing+students%27+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;stitle=Nurse+education+in+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.nepr.2024.103886&amp;title=Undergraduate+nursing+students%27+learning+experiences+using+design+thinking+on+a+human+development+course%3A+A+phenomenological+study&amp;volume=75&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=103886&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Undergraduate nursing students' learning experiences using design thinking on a human development course: A phenomenological study

'SurgTalk': The Educational Outcomes Associated With Development of a Surgical Podcast for Undergraduate Medical Students

Author: O'Neill, Susan1; Deegan, Joseph2; Ramjit, Sinéad1; Reynolds, John V1; Donohoe, Claire L11 Department of Surgery, Trinity Centre for Health Sciences, Trinity College Dublin and St James' Hospital, Dublin, Ireland oneils45@tcd.ie2 Acute Medical Unit, St James' Hospital, Dublin, Ireland

Publication info: O'Neill, Susan; Deegan, Joseph; Ramjit, Sinéad; Reynolds, John V; Donohoe, Claire L. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/surgtalk-educational-outcomes-associated-with/docview/2909086658/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Educational podcast series are becoming increasingly popular as free open access medical education (FOAMed) resources, however, the educational benefit associated with their use is unclear. The aim of this study was to assess the educational outcomes associated with the implementation of a surgical podcast series for undergraduate medical students. OBJECTIVE Educational podcast series are becoming increasingly popular as free open access medical education (FOAMed) resources, however, the educational benefit associated with their use is unclear. The aim of this study was to assess the educational outcomes associated with the implementation of a surgical podcast series for undergraduate medical students.Two conversational case-based podcast episodes were recorded covering 2 common surgical presentations. Final-year medical students were recruited prospectively in January 2023 and underwent a baseline multiple choice question (MCQ) test covering the material within the podcast episodes. Participants were then provided with the episode files through encrypted Google Drive links. Two weeks following baseline assessment, students repeated the initial MCQ test and completed a postpodcast reaction survey. Data were analyzed using a paired t-test, multivariable regression analyses, and simple descriptive statistics. METHODS Two conversational case-based podcast episodes were recorded covering 2 common surgical presentations. Final-year medical students were recruited prospectively in January 2023 and underwent a baseline multiple choice question (MCQ) test covering the material within the podcast episodes. Participants were then provided with the episode files through encrypted Google Drive links. Two weeks following baseline assessment, students repeated the initial MCQ test and completed a postpodcast reaction survey. Data were analyzed using a paired t-test, multivariable regression analyses, and simple descriptive statistics.Fifty students were enrolled in the study. All participants undertook the baseline assessment. About 98% completed the postpodcast MCQ, while 94% completed the postpodcast reaction survey. All participants who undertook the reaction survey (n = 47) found the podcast helpful in explaining surgical concepts, 92% of participants found the podcast enjoyable to listen to. The most commonly reported activity undertaken while listening was "commuting/driving" (n = 24, 48%). The mean baseline MCQ score was 44.6%. The mean postpodcast MCQ score was 65.51%. There was a mean absolute increase in test score of 20.2% from baseline which was statistically significant (95%CI 14.67-25.6, p < 0.001). RESULTS Fifty students were enrolled in the study. All participants undertook the baseline assessment. About 98% completed the postpodcast MCQ, while 94% completed the postpodcast reaction survey. All participants who undertook the reaction survey (n = 47) found the podcast helpful in explaining surgical concepts, 92% of participants found the podcast enjoyable to listen to. The most commonly reported activity undertaken while listening was "commuting/driving" (n = 24, 48%). The mean baseline MCQ score was 44.6%. The mean postpodcast MCQ score was 65.51%. There was a mean absolute increase in test score of 20.2% from baseline which was statistically significant (95%CI 14.67-25.6, p < 0.001).Implementation of this podcast series was associated with a statistically significant improvement in mean test score from baseline, reflecting knowledge acquisition. There was a positive user reaction and students were able to listen while performing other activities. Further evaluation of the educational outcomes associated with podcast use, particularly the effects on knowledge retention and clinical competence, is required. CONCLUSION Implementation of this podcast series was associated with a statistically significant improvement in mean test score from baseline, reflecting knowledge acquisition. There was a positive user reaction and students were able to listen while performing other activities. Further evaluation of the educational outcomes associated with podcast use, particularly the effects on knowledge retention and clinical competence, is required.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Susan&amp;aulast=O%27Neill&amp;atitle=%27SurgTalk%27%3A+The+Educational+Outcomes+Associated+With+Development+of+a+Surgical+Podcast+for+Undergraduate+Medical+Students&amp;stitle=Journal+of+surgical+education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jsurg.2023.10.008&amp;title=%27SurgTalk%27%3A+The+Educational+Outcomes+Associated+With+Development+of+a+Surgical+Podcast+for+Undergraduate+Medical+Students&amp;volume=81&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=202&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Susan&amp;aulast=O%27Neill&amp;atitle=%27SurgTalk%27%3A+The+Educational+Outcomes+Associated+With+Development+of+a+Surgical+Podcast+for+Undergraduate+Medical+Students&amp;stitle=Journal+of+surgical+education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jsurg.2023.10.008&amp;title=%27SurgTalk%27%3A+The+Educational+Outcomes+Associated+With+Development+of+a+Surgical+Podcast+for+Undergraduate+Medical+Students&amp;volume=81&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=202&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: 'SurgTalk': The Educational Outcomes Associated With Development of a Surgical Podcast for Undergraduate Medical Students

Enhancing postgraduate students’ learning outcomes through Flipped Mobile-Based Microlearning

Author: Al-Zahrani, Abdulrahman M.1    1 Educational Technology Department, University of Jeddah, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia ammzahrani@uj.edu.sa

Publication info: Al-Zahrani, Abdulrahman M. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/enhancing-postgraduate-students-learning-outcomes/docview/3034476802/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study examines the effects of implementing a Flipped Mobile-Based Microlearning (FMM) approach on postgraduate students’ accessibility, engagement, knowledge retention, overall learning experience and academic achievement. A quantitative multiple methods approach was employed, utilising a two-group quasi-experimental design and a survey questionnaire to gather data. The results suggest that the FMM approach may have positive effects on accessibility, engagement, knowledge retention, overall learning experience and final exam scores when compared to the traditional learning approach. The findings support the efficacy of integrating FMM, highlighting its potential for enhancing the learning process and academic outcomes. These results have implications for educational practice and research, emphasising the value of technology-enhanced learning approaches, active and interactive learning experiences and the promotion of student motivation and attitudes towards learning. This study underscores the broader applicability of FMM and suggests its potential for improving educational outcomes across different educational levels and subject areas. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2024 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Abdulrahman&amp;aulast=Al-Zahrani&amp;atitle=Enhancing+postgraduate+students%26rsquo%3B+learning+outcomes+through+Flipped+Mobile-Based+Microlearning&amp;stitle=Research+in+Learning+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.25304%2Frlt.v32.3110&amp;title=Enhancing+postgraduate+students%E2%80%99+learning+outcomes+through+Flipped+Mobile-Based+Microlearning&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

MDKLoss: Medicine domain knowledge loss for skin lesion recognition

Author: Zhang, Li1; Xiao, Xiangling2; Wen, Ju3; Li, Huihui21 The Second School of Clinical Medicine, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou 510515, China; Department of Dermatology, Guangdong Second Provincial General Hospital, Guangzhou 510317, China; Department of Dermatology, Ningbo No. 6 Hospital, Ningbo 315040, China2 School of Computer Science, Guangdong Polytechnic Normal University, Guangzhou 510665, China3 The Second School of Clinical Medicine, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou 510515, China; Department of Dermatology, Guangdong Second Provincial General Hospital, Guangzhou 510317, China

Publication info: Zhang, Li; Xiao, Xiangling; Wen, Ju; Li, Huihui. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/mdkloss-medicine-domain-knowledge-loss-skin/docview/2954770611/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Methods based on deep learning have shown good advantages in skin lesion recognition. However, the diversity of lesion shapes and the influence of noise disturbances such as hair, bubbles, and markers leads to large intra-class differences and small inter-class similarities, which existing methods have not yet effectively resolved. In addition, most existing methods enhance the performance of skin lesion recognition by improving deep learning models without considering the guidance of medical knowledge of skin lesions. In this paper, we innovatively construct feature associations between different lesions using medical knowledge, and design a medical domain knowledge loss function (MDKLoss) based on these associations. By expanding the gap between samples of various lesion categories, MDKLoss enhances the capacity of deep learning models to differentiate between different lesions and consequently boosts classification performance. Extensive experiments on ISIC2018 and ISIC2019 datasets show that the proposed method achieves a maximum of 91.6% and 87.6% accuracy. Furthermore, compared with existing state-of-the-art loss functions, the proposed method demonstrates its effectiveness, universality, and superiority.Methods based on deep learning have shown good advantages in skin lesion recognition. However, the diversity of lesion shapes and the influence of noise disturbances such as hair, bubbles, and markers leads to large intra-class differences and small inter-class similarities, which existing methods have not yet effectively resolved. In addition, most existing methods enhance the performance of skin lesion recognition by improving deep learning models without considering the guidance of medical knowledge of skin lesions. In this paper, we innovatively construct feature associations between different lesions using medical knowledge, and design a medical domain knowledge loss function (MDKLoss) based on these associations. By expanding the gap between samples of various lesion categories, MDKLoss enhances the capacity of deep learning models to differentiate between different lesions and consequently boosts classification performance. Extensive experiments on ISIC2018 and ISIC2019 datasets show that the proposed method achieves a maximum of 91.6% and 87.6% accuracy. Furthermore, compared with existing state-of-the-art loss functions, the proposed method demonstrates its effectiveness, universality, and superiority.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Li&amp;aulast=Zhang&amp;atitle=MDKLoss%3A+Medicine+domain+knowledge+loss+for+skin+lesion+recognition&amp;stitle=Mathematical+biosciences+and+engineering+%3A+MBE&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3934%2Fmbe.2024118&amp;title=MDKLoss%3A+Medicine+domain+knowledge+loss+for+skin+lesion+recognition&amp;volume=21&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=2671&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Developing an Implementation Strategy for Knowledge Management Practice in Architectural Firms

Author: Ngwenya, Leonorah

Publication info: Ngwenya, Leonorah. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/developing-implementation-strategy-knowledge/docview/3272304984/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study explored various knowledge management (KM) practices within architectural firms in South Africa, Gauteng province. The research aim was to explore how architects implement KM and identify the factors that encourage or hinder their KM practices. By doing so, the study aimed to develop an implementation strategy for KM practice in architectural firms in order to enhance KM, improve project outcomes and organisational performance. The investigation was grounded in Nonaka's theory of organisational knowledge creation from the dynamic interaction between tacit knowledge and explicit knowledge through socialisation, externalisation, combination, and internalisation (SECI). The research objectives were to determine architects' perspectives regarding KM, identify the factors that encourage architects to implement KM, investigate the challenges architects face when implementing KM, and develop an implementation strategy for KM practice in architectural firms. The research methodology to develop a KM implementation strategy adopted an interpretive research philosophy, utilising abductive reasoning to combine interview data with existing knowledge. A qualitative research design was employed with a multi-case study strategy. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with architects from five architectural firms to gather in-depth insights into their KM practices. The data collected were analysed thematically to identify patterns and draw meaningful conclusions about KM practices, challenges, and strategies. Findings from the study revealed that while large architectural firms tend to develop tailored KM systems, smaller firms often need more structured KM processes. The research highlighted the importance of fostering a learning culture within firms, which includes continuous professional development, open communication, and creating an environment conducive to knowledge sharing. The study emphasised the role of leadership in promoting KM and the need for management to support and participate actively in KM initiatives. The study underscored the crucial role of technology, particularly Building Information Modelling (BIM), in facilitating effective KM by providing platforms for storing, sharing, and accessing knowledge. BIM enhances design and construction processes and serves as a repository for project knowledge, thus aiding in the preservation and transfer of knowledge across projects. Despite the benefits of KM, several challenges were identified. These included difficulties in capturing and sharing tacit knowledge, time constraints, budget limitations, the temporary nature of project teams, lack of a systematic approach to KM leading to inefficiencies and knowledge loss. To address these challenges, the proposed KM implementation strategy recommends eleven action statements beginning with knowledge identification and ending with continuous improvement. The recommendation includes documentation protocols, promoting affordable technology solutions, facilitating knowledge sharing through workshops, and ensuring ethical iv and financial compliance, fostering a collaborative culture, investing in continuous professional development, and integrating KM into the firm's strategic objectives. The value of the proposed KM implementation strategy is the structured approach to KM that addresses the identified challenges and leverages the factors that encourage KM adoption. In this manner architectural firms can enhance their KM practices, improve project outcomes and overall organisational performance. In conclusion, the study underscored the critical role of KM in the architectural industry and provided actionable recommendations for architectural firms to improve their KM practices. The findings and recommendations from this study can help architectural firms in South Africa and beyond to harness the full potential of their knowledge assets, thereby achieving greater efficiency, innovation, and competitive advantage.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Leonorah&amp;aulast=Ngwenya&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Developing+an+Implementation+Strategy+for+Knowledge+Management+Practice+in+Architectural+Firms&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798263302115&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Leonorah&amp;aulast=Ngwenya&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Developing+an+Implementation+Strategy+for+Knowledge+Management+Practice+in+Architectural+Firms&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798263302115&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

An Interpretation of VhaVenda and AmaZulu Waist Belts: Coloniality of Culture

Author: Mthethwa, Khanya

Publication info: Mthethwa, Khanya. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/interpretation-vhavenda-amazulu-waist-belts/docview/3272302453/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This thesis examines the enduring influence of coloniality on the cultural practices and material heritage of the AmaZulu and VhaVenda people, with a specific focus on waist belts as symbols of identity, resilience, and adaptation. Through the lens of coloniality of culture, the study traces how colonial power has reconfigured indigenous knowledge systems and reshaped cultural expressions, often relegating them to the periphery of wider societal narratives. This research engages directly with AmaZulu and VhaVenda women as co-researchers using decolonial methodologies rooted in relational ontology and epistemology. Their dialogues offer varied insights into the waist belts’ symbolic and practical roles across generations and geographies. Through these conversations, the study explores the differences in cultural knowledge retention and interpretation between urban and rural communities, highlighting the intersection of gender, location, and colonial influence. The analysis reveals how waist belts, such as the Venda muvhofho and the Zulu isifociya, encapsulate the layered histories of cultural continuity, resistance, and transformation. These objects, often dismissed as mere "craft," are reframed as critical sites of indigenous knowledge and lived experience. This work advocates for a reconceptualization of indigenous material culture within academic discourse, challenging the dominance of Eurocentric paradigms and emphasizing the importance of preserving and valuing indigenous perspectives. Through this decolonial inquiry, the thesis contributes to the broader conversation on how material culture can illuminate the persistent effects of coloniality and serves as a call to reimagine research practices that center and respect indigenous voices.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Khanya&amp;aulast=Mthethwa&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=An+Interpretation+of+VhaVenda+and+AmaZulu+Waist+Belts%3A+Coloniality+of+Culture&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798263304294&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Simulação clínica virtual em contexto hospitalar: uma estratégia pedagógica na formação contínua em Enfermagem

Author: Cunha, Daniel José

Publication info: Cunha, Daniel José. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/simulação-clínica-virtual-em-contexto-hospitalar/docview/3271693463/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The continuous advancement of science and technology in healthcare demands an adequate response from healthcare institutions and professionals to uphold the standards of healthcare quality and safety. Leveraging Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) emerges as a promising solution for enhancing access to continuing education. Therefore, implementing an m-learning strategy tailored to the specific requirements of healthcare professionals, developed by expert trainers, and endorsed by reputable institutions stands out as an optimal approach to meet this objective. This study aimed to implement a pedagogical approach using mobile learning within the context of continuing education in nursing in a hospital environment. This initiative is underpinned by Information and Communication Technologies (ICT), the dematerialization of the traditional training model, and the incorporation of gamified learning methodologies. The study was conducted in three phases: preparation, development and implementation, and evaluation. An exploratory and descriptive study, followed by a quasi-experimental study employing pre- and post-test, were carried out. A panel of experts in continuing education in nursing participated in the development phase. The evaluation phase included a non-probabilistic convenience sample of 168 nurses recruited from the Medical Department of a hospital in northern Portugal who freely accepted to participate in the study. Based on the findings of the preparatory phase, a pedagogical strategy was developed and implemented and made accessible through a Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) format available on an online platform. This MOOC incorporated virtual clinical simulation to enhance clinical decision-making skills. The outcomes indicate a high level of satisfaction among nurses after using the MOOC – Ecare COPD - and their intention to integrate this pedagogical approach into their continuing education (M=4.50; DP±0.59). Participants perceived the MOOC as highly useful (M=4.43; SD±0.64) and easy to use (M=4.46; SD±0.64). The strategy’s efficacy was significant for knowledge retention [t (167) = 16.697, p<.001, Cohen's d =1.28], and its characteristics greatly contributed to the high completion rates. This study produced exciting outcomes since it enabled the identification of essential components critical for developing this pedagogical strategy. This approach holds promise in ensuring the safety and quality of care while aligning with healthcare professionals’ expectations and demands.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Daniel&amp;aulast=Cunha&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Simula%C3%A7%C3%A3o+cl%C3%ADnica+virtual+em+contexto+hospitalar%3A+uma+estrat%C3%A9gia+pedag%C3%B3gica+na+forma%C3%A7%C3%A3o+cont%C3%ADnua+em+Enfermagem&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798297966666&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Daniel&amp;aulast=Cunha&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Simula%C3%A7%C3%A3o+cl%C3%ADnica+virtual+em+contexto+hospitalar%3A+uma+estrat%C3%A9gia+pedag%C3%B3gica+na+forma%C3%A7%C3%A3o+cont%C3%ADnua+em+Enfermagem&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798297966666&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Plataforma de Informação para o Fogo - Como melhorar o Engagement através de tecnologias interativas e Design Centrado no Utilizador

Author: Oliveira, Letícia Alexandra Coelho

Publication info: Oliveira, Letícia Alexandra Coelho. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/plataforma-de-informação-para-o-fogo-como/docview/3271063032/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The communication of Wildfire knowledge on the web is extensive, with numerous sources distributing information on the topic. However, most of the content available targets specialists, researchers, and stakeholders, failing to engage wider non-specialized audiences. Integrated into the FIRE-RES Project, our goal is twofold: 1) understand how Multimedia Interactive Technologies can improve engagement and make Fire Knowledge more accessible and intuitive, and 2) create a Fire Information Platform that aggregates information on Fire resilience. The research methodology is divided into two phases. The first is focused on understanding the research context and target audience and uses a mix of traditional and user-centered research methods: Literature Review on Risk and Science Communication on the web and possibilities of Multimedia Technologies; UX Benchmarking of selected solutions; Online survey with the targeted audience, and 4) Collaborative Ideation session. The survey gathered 811 answers that revealed the general understanding, habits, and information sources regarding wildfire knowledge. In addition to that, we selected five web solutions and explored three multimedia features adopted to enhance information dissemination: gamification, interactivity, and narratives. These data informed the second phase, which involved an analysis of the preliminary results and the design of high-fidelity prototypes. These were later subjected to usability testing with a few relevant personas. Ultimately, the study reveals the potential of Digital Technologies in Science Communication and demonstrates that adopting a user-centered approach facilitates content adaptation to users and increases engagement, accessibility, and knowledge retention. By making essential fire information more intuitive and engaging for different audiences, we expect to contribute to wildfire prevention in Portugal and abroad.

Framework for Interactive, Individualized Feedback Design to Improve Thinking Skills in Construction Education

Author: An, Mi Sun

Publication info: An, Mi Sun. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/framework-interactive-individualized-feedback/docview/3268512516/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Organizational improvement relies heavily on having a competent workforce. To facilitate continuous improvement in the construction industry, this study examined the weaknesses in problem-solving skills among today's students (the future workforce). Based on these findings, a new educational approach was proposed, taking today’s student characteristics such as Acquired Attention Deficit Disorder (AADD) into consideration. This proposed educational approach was proved to have immediate and lasting effects beyond class periods on students’ learning through improved thinking skill exercises. Initial investigations focused on identifying weaknesses in exercising adequate thinking skills in problem-solving and determining the cause beyond the weaknesses. Weaknesses were identified when faced with information processing, locating inputs from multiple sources, repeating the same cognitive processes over extended periods, unfamiliar calculation direction, and ignoring industry common sense due to a calculation-oriented mindset. The lack of fundamentals was identified as the primary cause of the weakness. To resolve the weaknesses by addressing the cause behind the weaknesses, a new educational approach was proposed and validated through a mixed method. First, a feedback framework was designed which functions for knowledge delivery. Feedback was designed to deliver highly relevant knowledge to the problem at hand and to be presented in a size to allow easy information consumption in real-time considering the target students’ characteristics and learning preferences, Generation Z. Feedback, a knowledge delivery tool, had immediate effects on exercising thinking skills in problem-solving on a sample of 13 graduate-level students in the Department of Construction Science at Texas A&M University who volunteered for the experiment and the following interview. Especially, two factors of feedback were counted as the key to improving thinking skills, and they are the feedback that was given immediately in real-time when it was in need (when in need) and the feedback that matched the target knowledge in question (what is needed). The design feedback also had a lasting impact on exercising adequate thinking skills, by which improved academic achievement was demonstrated in a sample of 24 students enrolled in a construction estimating course for undergraduate students at Western Kentucky University. The result of the paired t-test evidenced the effectiveness of feedback on knowledge retention and academic achievement. Additionally, 71% of 24 study participants responded to the self-confidence survey, and the positive self-confidence in exercising thinking skills in each category in Bloom’s Taxonomy also denoted the efficacy of knowledge feeding in feedback. This study theoretically expanded types of feedback by adding knowledge delivery to the existing feedback types. With this addition, feedback now functions not only giving confirmation or correction for the performance, but it also functions as a vehicle for knowledge delivery. Pragmatically, this study proposed a novel educational approach which aligns with today’s students’ learning preferences and weaknesses.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mi&amp;aulast=An&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Framework+for+Interactive%2C+Individualized+Feedback+Design+to+Improve+Thinking+Skills+in+Construction+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798297981911&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mi&amp;aulast=An&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Framework+for+Interactive%2C+Individualized+Feedback+Design+to+Improve+Thinking+Skills+in+Construction+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798297981911&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

A Construção de Um Mosaico Educacional por Meio da Utilização do Microlearning na Educação Superior a Distância : Percepções de Técnicos Pedagógicos de Uma Ies de Santa Catarina

Author: Martins, Jairo

Publication info: Martins, Jairo. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/construção-de-um-mosaico-educacional-por-meio-da/docview/3235007933/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: O avanço tecnológico, impulsionado pela globalização, transformou o cenário educacional, adaptando-o às novas relações sociais e possibilitando um maior acesso aos alunos. No Brasil, a educação a distância (EAD) teve um aumento expressivo, com um crescimento de 474% em dez anos, segundo dados do Instituto Nacional de Estudos e Pesquisas Educacionais Anísio Teixeira (Brasil, 2022). Esse crescimento pode ser atribuído, entre outros, ao contexto tecnológico da sociedade atual, em que os ‘nativos digitais’ têm acesso precoce e familiaridade com as tecnologias digitais (Prensky, 2010). Os nativos digitais interagem constantemente com as Tecnologias Digitais de Informação e Comunicação, influenciando suas experiências em acessar, distribuir, criar e interagir com informações. Contudo, a ascensão dessa sociedade acostumada a múltiplos estímulos apresenta desafios para a educação, especialmente no EAD. Pesquisas mostram que vídeos breves no YouTube , com menos de quatro minutos, recebem mais visualizações e maior interação do que vídeos mais longos (Redondo et al., 2021). Esse comportamento de consumo afeta a educação, destacando a importância de novas abordagens pedagógicas. Nesse ambiente, o microlearning surge como uma abordagem suplementar que atende às demandas dos alunos modernos, envolvendo a entrega de microconteúdos que podem ser consumidos em até cinco minutos, resumindo conceitos essenciais de um curso ou disciplina específica (Torgerson; Iannone, 2020). Este estudo propõe investigar o microlearning como estratégia de aprendizagem no ensino superior, especialmente em cursos de pós-graduação lato sensu na modalidade EAD, com a pergunta: em que medida o microlearning pode ser relevante para a educação no contexto de cursos de pós-graduação EAD? Esta pesquisa faz parte do Programa de Pós-Graduação em Educação, Mestrado em Educação, da Universidade Regional de Blumenau (FURB), e está inserida na linha de pesquisa Linguagens, Arte e Educação. O objetivo geral é analisar potencialidades educativas do microlearning , por meio das impressões do corpo técnico-pedagógico de uma instituição de ensino superior de Santa Catarina. Os objetivos específicos são: (I) aplicar uma proposta de implantação do microlearning para uma formação com o corpo técnico-pedagógico da instituição; (II) identificar elementos significativos do microlearning no processo de aprendizagem; (III) refletir sobre a utilização do microlearning na educação. O estudo adota uma abordagem qualitativa (Flick, 2009) e caracteriza-se como pesquisa-ação (Thiollent, 2011). A metodologia foi implementada em um curso com o corpo técnico de uma IES, dividindo o contingente em dois grupos. O grupo de controle fez o curso sem acesso ao microlearning , enquanto o grupo experimental teve acesso aos materiais de microlearning via e-mail . Para este grupo, formou-se um grupo de interlocução de sete colaboradores, entrevistados para identificar o impacto do microlearning na aprendizagem. A coleta de dados foi realizada por meio de questionários e entrevistas, analisados com base no referencial teórico de Bardin (2016). Os resultados apontam uma contribuição significativa do microlearning no aumento do engajamento, melhora na retenção do conhecimento e um ganho substancial no desempenho acadêmico entre os participantes do grupo experimental, os quais apresentaram uma taxa de conclusão superior em comparação ao grupo de controle. Alternate abstract: The advancement of technology, driven by globalization, has transformed the educational landscape, adapting it to new social relations and enabling greater access to students. In Brazil, distance education (DE) has seen a significant increase, with a growth of 474% over ten years, according to data from the National Institute for Educational Studies and Research Anísio Teixeira (Brazil, 2022). This growth may be attributed to the technological context of today’s society, in which 'digital natives' have early access and familiarity with digital technologies (Prensky, 2010). Digital natives constantly interact with Digital Information and Communication Technologies, influencing their experiences in accessing, distributing, creating, and interacting with information. However, the rise of this stimulus-rich society poses challenges for education, especially in DE. Research shows that brief YouTube videos, under four minutes, receive more views and greater engagement than longer videos (Redondo et al., 2021). This consumption behavior impacts education, highlighting the importance of new pedagogical approaches. In this environment, microlearning emerges as a supplemental approach that meets the demands of modern students, involving the delivery of microcontent that can be consumed in up to five minutes, summarizing essential concepts of a course or specific subject (Torgerson and Iannone, 2020). This study proposes investigating microlearning as a learning strategy in higher education, particularly in lato sensu graduate courses in DE, with the question: to what extent can microlearning be relevant to education in the context of DE graduate courses? This research study is part of the Graduate Program in Education, Master’s in Education, at the Regional University of Blumenau (FURB), and is aligned with the research field of Languages, Art, and Education. The general objective is to analyze the educational potential of microlearning through the perspectives of the technicalpedagogical staff of a higher education institution in Santa Catarina. The specific objectives are: (I) to apply a microlearning implementation proposal for training with the institution's technical-pedagogical staff; (II) to identify significant elements of microlearning in the learning process; (III) to reflect on the use of microlearning in education. The study adopts a qualitative approach (Flick, 2009) and is characterized as action research (Thiollent, 2011). The methodology was implemented in a course with the technical staff of a Higher Education Institution, dividing the contingent into two groups. The control group took the course without access to microlearning, while the experimental group had access to microlearning materials via email. For this group, an interlocution group of seven collaborators was formed and interviewed to identify the impact of microlearning on learning. Data collection was conducted through questionnaires and interviews, analyzed based on Bardin’s theoretical framework (2016). The results indicate a significant contribution of microlearning in increasing engagement, improving knowledge retention, and a substantial gain in academic performance among the experimental group participants, who showed a higher completion rate compared to the control group. It was evident that segmenting content into microcontent contributed to learning that is more aligned to the needs of contemporary students, demonstrating the potential of microlearning as a relevant complementary methodology for DE in graduate courses.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jairo&amp;aulast=Martins&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=A+Constru%C3%A7%C3%A3o+de+Um+Mosaico+Educacional+por+Meio+da+Utiliza%C3%A7%C3%A3o+do+Microlearning+na+Educa%C3%A7%C3%A3o+Superior+a+Dist%C3%A2ncia+%3A+Percep%C3%A7%C3%B5es+de+T%C3%A9cnicos+Pedag%C3%B3gicos+de+Uma+Ies+de+Santa+Catarina&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798290624389&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Title: A Construção de Um Mosaico Educacional por Meio da Utilização do Microlearning na Educação Superior a Distância : Percepções de Técnicos Pedagógicos de Uma Ies de Santa Catarina
