International Teachers’ Perspective on How Breaks in Instruction Affect Knowledge Retention in International K-12 Schools: A Phenomenological Study

Author: McIntosh, Conrad Lancelot

Publication info: McIntosh, Conrad Lancelot. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/international-teachers-perspective-on-how-breaks/docview/3175915935/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The impact of breaks in direct instruction on knowledge retention among international K-12 students, focusing on teachers’ lived experiences, was explored in this study. The objective of this research study was to examine the challenges during instructional disruptions and identify strategies to maintain continuity and reduce knowledge loss. Understanding effective methods to manage extended breaks, particularly considering the widening achievement gap due to disruptions such as natural disasters and health crises such as COVID-19, was emphasized. A qualitative phenomenological approach was used to gather in-depth experiences from international teachers who live and work in South Carolina through semi-structured interviews. Nine teachers from diverse regions, including the Caribbean, Asia, South America, and Europe participated. Several key findings were uncovered from the interviews. These findings included disruptions in instruction significantly hinder continuity, leading to challenges in learning and retention. Strategies to manage disruptions included shifting to online platforms, frequent review sessions, and increased parental involvement. However, technological challenges such as limited access to devices and internet connectivity created barriers to seamless instruction, necessitating institutional support. Recommendations were presented for robust protocols, adaptable teaching methods, and strategic technology to support continuous learning during disruptions. Suggestions include training teachers in online instruction, implementing contingency plans, fostering greater parental engagement, and improving access to digital resources. Practical insights are presented for educators and policymakers to develop resilient educational practices that ensure inclusive and continuous learning, even during instructional breaks.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Conrad&amp;aulast=McIntosh&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=International+Teachers%E2%80%99+Perspective+on+How+Breaks+in+Instruction+Affect+Knowledge+Retention+in+International+K-12+Schools%3A+A+Phenomenological+Study&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798310103504&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Unlocking Potential: The Transformative Role of Gaming in Rural Higher Learning Institutions of South Africa -- A Systematic Exploration

Author: Mbukanma, Ifeanyi; Manganyi, Madira; Vellem, Bhekithemba; Gqoli, Neliswa

Publication info: Mbukanma, Ifeanyi; Manganyi, Madira; Vellem, Bhekithemba; Gqoli, Neliswa. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/unlocking-potential-transformative-role-gaming/docview/3174442552/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The aim of this study resonated with the pursuit of achieving enhanced engagement in teaching and learning that informs critical thinking, and knowledge retention among students. Despite the growing trend of technological integration in teaching and learning, however, there exists a lack of empirical evidence and comprehensive studies that investigate the effectiveness of gaming in promoting educational objectives within rural institution of higher learning in South Africa. To investigate this gap, a systematic review method was employed, which provides a comprehensive and logical analysis of existing literature on the significance of gaming in teaching and learning within rural institutions of higher education. Inclusion and exclusion criteria were used in the study to enhance the rigor and transparency of the research process, by providing a solid foundation for synthesizing and interpreting existing literature relevant to the study. The systematic review findings revealed that the significance of gamification in teaching and learning in rural higher education lies in its ability to overcome accessibility challenges, provide personalized learning experiences, address motivation and retention issues, and enhance digital literacy. It was recommended that by incorporating gamified approaches, rural higher educational institutions can create a more inclusive, engaging, and effective learning environment for students within the rural institutions of higher learning in South Africa.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ifeanyi&amp;aulast=Mbukanma&amp;atitle=Unlocking+Potential%3A+The+Transformative+Role+of+Gaming+in+Rural+Higher+Learning+Institutions+of+South+Africa+--+A+Systematic+Exploration&amp;stitle=Research+in+Social+Sciences+and+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Unlocking+Potential%3A+The+Transformative+Role+of+Gaming+in+Rural+Higher+Learning+Institutions+of+South+Africa+--+A+Systematic+Exploration&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=140&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Instructional Toolkit for Outcome-Based Instruction on English Grammatical Literacy of Thai EFL Students

Author: Karanjakwut, Chalermsup

Publication info: Karanjakwut, Chalermsup. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/instructional-toolkit-outcome-based-instruction/docview/3174441562/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a new instructional toolkit for improving English grammar skills, particularly verb tense structures, among Thai EFL students. The research objectives were (1) to evaluate the toolkit's effectiveness in enhancing students' English grammar skills in verb tense structures; (2) to examine the impact on Thai EFL students' learning achievement; (3) to assess knowledge retention after using the toolkit; (4) to analyze relationships among study levels, English proficiency levels, and learning achievement before and after toolkit use; (5) to explore students' perceptions of the toolkit's design, retention development, and implementation. The sample consisted of 200 students (100 primary and 100 secondary) from public schools in Bangkok's Thonburi district, using a multi-level group research design. Data collection instruments included the instructional toolkit, achievement tests, questionnaires, and interviews. Data were gathered before, during, and after the intervention, and analyzed using both quantitative (SPSS) and qualitative (content analysis) methods. The research revealed that 95 percent of students and teachers acknowledged the toolkit's efficiency and efficacy, with significant improvements noted post-intervention. The toolkit effectively enhanced knowledge retention in verb tense structures across different educational levels, showing particular resonance with higher-grade students and those at intermediate proficiency. Practical implications of the findings include (1) the need for school policies to mandate OBE-aligned toolkits with age-appropriate designs, and (2) the importance of incorporating self-paced, practical language application opportunities for Thai EFL students. This study contributes to discourses on instructional innovation in EFL contexts by underscoring tailored toolkits' potential to address specific linguistic challenges while aligning with educational reforms. Future research could explore adaptability across age groups, design variations, and other complex linguistic elements.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Chalermsup&amp;aulast=Karanjakwut&amp;atitle=Instructional+Toolkit+for+Outcome-Based+Instruction+on+English+Grammatical+Literacy+of+Thai+EFL+Students&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Education+and+Literacy+Studies&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Instructional+Toolkit+for+Outcome-Based+Instruction+on+English+Grammatical+Literacy+of+Thai+EFL+Students&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=14&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Chalermsup&amp;aulast=Karanjakwut&amp;atitle=Instructional+Toolkit+for+Outcome-Based+Instruction+on+English+Grammatical+Literacy+of+Thai+EFL+Students&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Education+and+Literacy+Studies&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Instructional+Toolkit+for+Outcome-Based+Instruction+on+English+Grammatical+Literacy+of+Thai+EFL+Students&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=14&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

An Interest-Oriented Laboratory Microbial Engineering Course Is Helpful for the Cultivation of Scientific Literacy

Author: Wu, Genfu; Wu, Kejie

Publication info: Wu, Genfu; Wu, Kejie. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/interest-oriented-laboratory-microbial/docview/3174440639/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) exposes an entire class of students to scientific research and is thought to increase students' knowledge retention in science, technology, engineering and mathematics education. Microbial engineering is an interdisciplinary subject that combines science and engineering. We transformed a microbial engineering course into a CURE-type course by adopting an interest-oriented case teaching approach. Based on an investigation of the interest of students, which showed that the topics related to food and health were students' favourites, we selected beer brewing, glutamate fermentation and Monascus cultivation as teaching topics. To simulate the reality of industrial fermentation, pilot-scale fermentation equipment was selected and installed. The course focused on fermentation research; most of the time was spent on performing experiments, and theoretical lectures were held at the intervals. To complete the course in 10 days, three series of experiments were alternatively carried out, and students took turns to conduct fermentation control and process analyses in groups. A questionnaire survey showed that students were satisfied with the CURE-type course, their fermentation knowledge and engineering skills were improved, their research abilities were developed, and their scientific attitudes were cultivated. CURE-type courses are worth popularising in biology teaching.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Genfu&amp;aulast=Wu&amp;atitle=An+Interest-Oriented+Laboratory+Microbial+Engineering+Course+Is+Helpful+for+the+Cultivation+of+Scientific+Literacy&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Biological+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F00219266.2022.2147575&amp;title=An+Interest-Oriented+Laboratory+Microbial+Engineering+Course+Is+Helpful+for+the+Cultivation+of+Scientific+Literacy&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1035&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Genfu&amp;aulast=Wu&amp;atitle=An+Interest-Oriented+Laboratory+Microbial+Engineering+Course+Is+Helpful+for+the+Cultivation+of+Scientific+Literacy&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Biological+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F00219266.2022.2147575&amp;title=An+Interest-Oriented+Laboratory+Microbial+Engineering+Course+Is+Helpful+for+the+Cultivation+of+Scientific+Literacy&amp;volume=58&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1035&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Desktop-Based Virtual Reality Social Platforms versus Video Conferencing Platforms for Online Synchronous Learning in Higher Education: An Experimental Study to Evaluate Students' Learning Gains and User Experience

Author: Di Natale, Anna Flavia    ; Repetto, Claudia    ; Villani, Daniela    

Publication info: Di Natale, Anna Flavia; Repetto, Claudia; Villani, Daniela. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/desktop-based-virtual-reality-social-platforms/docview/3174439142/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: Online synchronous learning in higher education frequently struggles to overcome the social presence gap, resulting in dissatisfaction and poor learning outcomes. Objectives: This study examined the effectiveness of desktop-based virtual reality (VR) social platforms compared to video conferencing (VC) platforms in enhancing students' learning gains and experiences in online synchronous learning. Methods: The study used a within-subject design, involving 34 college students in two online lecture modules, one via a VR social platform and another through a VC platform. Knowledge assessments occurred pre- and post-modules and after 1 week. Students also completed post-module questionnaires to evaluate their learning experience, in terms of social presence, easiness of use and perceived emotions. In-depth interviews provided further insights into their experiences with both platforms. Results: The study showed that using VR social platforms for online synchronous learning enhanced immediate knowledge, especially in students less interested in the content, yet it did not notably impact long-term knowledge retention. Despite no significant findings in social presence from questionnaires, interviews indicated that the VR's heightened interactivity might be offset by the effect of not seeing others' real appearances in promoting social presence. Furthermore, the VC platform was found to be easier to use, attributed to its familiarity and user-friendliness. Finally, students experienced increased fun, awe and interest, along with reduced boredom, when using the VR social platform. Conclusion: The findings highlight the potential of VR to enrich online learning while underscoring the need for effective strategies facilitating a smooth integration into educational settings.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Anna&amp;aulast=Di+Natale&amp;atitle=Desktop-Based+Virtual+Reality+Social+Platforms+versus+Video+Conferencing+Platforms+for+Online+Synchronous+Learning+in+Higher+Education%3A+An+Experimental+Study+to+Evaluate+Students%27+Learning+Gains+and+User+Experience&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Computer+Assisted+Learning&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fjcal.13075&amp;title=Desktop-Based+Virtual+Reality+Social+Platforms+versus+Video+Conferencing+Platforms+for+Online+Synchronous+Learning+in+Higher+Education%3A+An+Experimental+Study+to+Evaluate+Students%27+Learning+Gains+and+User+Experience&amp;volume=40&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=3454&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

The Voice Quality of Pedagogical Agent Impacts Learning and Agent Perceptions

Author: Siegle, Robert F; Craig, Scotty D    

Publication info: Siegle, Robert F; Craig, Scotty D. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/voice-quality-pedagogical-agent-impacts-learning/docview/3174438693/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: The voices virtual on-screen characters use has been shown to impact learning and perception outcomes. Recent replication research on these voices showed that synthetic voices were not a detriment if produced by a high-quality engine with clear articulation. The current manuscript examines previous accent research that utilized now outdated engines, to determine if the impact of accents still holds with high-quality engines and voice actors. Objectives: To investigate the impact on learning and perceptions with pedagogical agents speaking in accented voices, synthetic voices, and the interaction between the two using modern voice engines. Methods: This study is a between-subjects two (accent) by two (type) factorial design to determine the impact the voice accent, voice type, and the interaction have on learning retention, learning transfer, mental effort efficiency, and perception measures. 197 participants were recruited from the online Amazon's Mechanical Turk with qualifications of 18 years of age, "normal or corrected-to-normal hearing", and located with the continental United States of America. Results and Conclusions: There were no significant differences between the accented conditions or interaction effects, deviating from previous research that showed impact of accents on learning. The synthetic condition had significantly lower knowledge retention, knowledge transfer, mental effort efficiency, and perception measures than the human professional. These findings demonstrate the importance of considering voice quality when designing pedagogical agents. Previous research showed synthetic voices perform as well as the average voice, and this research continues the narrative of voice quality by showing professional recordings outperform modern synthetic engines.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Robert&amp;aulast=Siegle&amp;atitle=The+Voice+Quality+of+Pedagogical+Agent+Impacts+Learning+and+Agent+Perceptions&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Computer+Assisted+Learning&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fjcal.13027&amp;title=The+Voice+Quality+of+Pedagogical+Agent+Impacts+Learning+and+Agent+Perceptions&amp;volume=40&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=2278&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Robert&amp;aulast=Siegle&amp;atitle=The+Voice+Quality+of+Pedagogical+Agent+Impacts+Learning+and+Agent+Perceptions&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Computer+Assisted+Learning&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fjcal.13027&amp;title=The+Voice+Quality+of+Pedagogical+Agent+Impacts+Learning+and+Agent+Perceptions&amp;volume=40&amp;issue=5&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=2278&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Enhancing Postgraduate Students' Learning Outcomes through Flipped Mobile-Based Microlearning

Author: Al-Zahrani, Abdulrahman M    

Publication info: Al-Zahrani, Abdulrahman M. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/enhancing-postgraduate-students-learning-outcomes/docview/3174408614/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study examines the effects of implementing a Flipped Mobile-Based Microlearning (FMM) approach on postgraduate students' accessibility, engagement, knowledge retention, overall learning experience and academic achievement. A quantitative multiple methods approach was employed, utilising a two-group quasi-experimental design and a survey questionnaire to gather data. The results suggest that the FMM approach may have positive effects on accessibility, engagement, knowledge retention, overall learning experience and final exam scores when compared to the traditional learning approach. The findings support the efficacy of integrating FMM, highlighting its potential for enhancing the learning process and academic outcomes. These results have implications for educational practice and research, emphasising the value of technology-enhanced learning approaches, active and interactive learning experiences and the promotion of student motivation and attitudes towards learning. This study underscores the broader applicability of FMM and suggests its potential for improving educational outcomes across different educational levels and subject areas.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Abdulrahman&amp;aulast=Al-Zahrani&amp;atitle=Enhancing+Postgraduate+Students%27+Learning+Outcomes+through+Flipped+Mobile-Based+Microlearning&amp;stitle=Research+in+Learning+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Enhancing+Postgraduate+Students%27+Learning+Outcomes+through+Flipped+Mobile-Based+Microlearning&amp;volume=32&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Nursing Faculty Experiences Creating and Using Short Videos to Engage Prelicensure Nursing Students

Author: Hahn, Alyssa

Publication info: Hahn, Alyssa. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/nursing-faculty-experiences-creating-using-short/docview/3174398825/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to explore nursing faculty experiences in creating and using short videos to engage prelicensure nursing students. Short videos are an innovative teaching strategy to help engage learners by decreasing cognitive workload and increasing knowledge retention. Learner engagement in prelicensure nursing education is imperative for the development of the clinical judgment skills necessary for safe and effective patient care. There is a lack of nursing education literature on the creation and use of short videos and limited literature using the cognitive theory of multimedia learning (CTML) as the theoretical framework in nursing education. The research question is as follows: What are nursing faculty experiences creating and using short videos to engage prelicensure nursing students? The cognitive theory of multimedia learning in conjunction with the domains of learner engagement was used as the theoretical framework for this study. Fourteen semi-structured interviews were gathered using a basic qualitative inquiry approach. The information-rich data was analyzed using Braun and Clarke's thematic analysis to find five themes and two subthemes. Participants shared a similar process in how they selected or created videos to use in their didactic course. The five themes are identified gaps in instructional plan, established criteria for using videos, related videos to an activity or discussion, positive student reactions, and increase in student engagement. Findings from this study add to the body of knowledge about creating or using short videos in nursing education. Practical implications include recommendations for the effective incorporation of short videos into the didactic portion of the course to engage prelicensure nursing students. Future research that includes nursing students as participants, graduate nursing faculty as participants, exploring the individual CTML principles in nursing education, how short videos impact student performance, and how short videos impact knowledge retention is needed. [The dissertation citations contained here are published with the permission of ProQuest LLC. Further reproduction is prohibited without permission. Copies of dissertations may be obtained by Telephone (800) 1-800-521-0600. Web page: http://www.proquest.com/en-US/products/dissertations/individuals.shtml.]

Strategies to Enhance Employee Knowledge Retention in Public and Private Universities

Author: Iyiola, Funmilola Adebunmi

Publication info: Iyiola, Funmilola Adebunmi. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/strategies-enhance-employee-knowledge-retention/docview/3174395952/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Retaining an employee's knowledge becomes a significant challenge when skilled and experienced employees leave an organization. Human resources (HR) professionals/leaders at public and private universities are particularly concerned about the detrimental impact of knowledge loss in such cases. Grounded in the knowledge management cycle (KMC) model, the purpose of this qualitative multiple case study was to explore strategies that HR professionals/leaders of public and private universities use to enhance employee knowledge retention. The participants were nine HR professionals/leaders in public and private universities who successfully enhanced employee knowledge retention. Data were collected using semistructured interviews and a review of publicly available company documentation. Through thematic analysis, four themes were identified: (a) mentoring and coaching, (b) creating a culture of learning and development, (c) employee engagement culture, and (d) effective knowledge repository system. A key recommendation for HR professionals/leaders is to create an environment of trust, openness, and excellent relationships with the university's employees. The implications for positive social include the potential for HR professionals/leaders at public and private universities to drive competitive advantage and business growth, enhance employee well-being, and expand job opportunities and sustainability in local communities. [The dissertation citations contained here are published with the permission of ProQuest LLC. Further reproduction is prohibited without permission. An Interactive Web App Playbook with an AI Assistant for Improving Organizational Communication

Author: Wen Yang Tan1; Nicholas Heng Loong Wong11 Infocomm Technology Singapore Institute of Technology,Singapore

Publication info: Wen Yang Tan; Nicholas Heng Loong Wong. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/interactive-web-app-playbook-with-ai-assistant/docview/3174167801/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: TENCON 2024 - 2024 IEEE Region 10 Conference (TENCON) Conference Start Date: 2024, Dec. 1 Conference End Date: 2024, Dec. 4 Conference Location: Singapore, Singapore In today's fast-paced organizational environments, the need for engaging and effective knowledge transfer tools is paramount. Traditional static playbooks often fail to engage, and hence, support knowledge retention by their users in organizations. This paper presents a realization of an interactive web app playbook, meant to mitigate these challenges and provide a dynamic and user-friendly platform that fosters high engagement, simplification of complex methodologies, and improved transfer of knowledge. The intuitive interface is complemented by an AI-based chatbot assistant to provide contextually relevant and personalized responses to user queries. Our study has found that the interactive playbook considerably improves user engagement, comprehension, and knowledge retention.

Approximate Bisimulation Relation Restoration for Neural Networks Based On Knowledge Distillation

Author: Chen, Jie1; Mo, Zihao2; Wang, Tao1; Xiang, Weiming21 School of Electrical Engineering, Southwest Jiaotong University,Chengdu,China2 School of Computer and Cyber Sciences, Augusta University,Augusta,GA,USA,30901

Publication info: Chen, Jie; Mo, Zihao; Wang, Tao; Xiang, Weiming. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/approximate-bisimulation-relation-restoration/docview/3174162190/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications (ICMLA) Conference Start Date: 2024, Dec. 18 Conference End Date: 2024, Dec. 20 Conference Location: Miami, FL, USA This paper employs knowledge distillation to optimize neural network compression processes via reducing the approximate bisimulation error between two neural networks. The paper calculates the approximate bisimulation error between two neural networks and derives the relationship between the approximate bisimulation error and the soft loss of knowledge distillation processes. Then, we propose a knowledge distillation optimization framework to further reduce the approximate bisimulation error between the original neural network and its compressed version. This method can significantly enhance the trustworthiness of the neural network compression methods as the approximate bisimulation error is reduced.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jie&amp;aulast=Chen&amp;atitle=Approximate+Bisimulation+Relation+Restoration+for+Neural+Networks+Based+On+Knowledge+Distillation&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FICMLA61862.2024.00137&amp;title=Approximate+Bisimulation+Relation+Restoration+for+Neural+Networks+Based+On+Knowledge+Distillation&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jie&amp;aulast=Chen&amp;atitle=Approximate+Bisimulation+Relation+Restoration+for+Neural+Networks+Based+On+Knowledge+Distillation&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FICMLA61862.2024.00137&amp;title=Approximate+Bisimulation+Relation+Restoration+for+Neural+Networks+Based+On+Knowledge+Distillation&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Subject: Errors; Neural networks; Machine learning; Distillation; Optimization

Title: Approximate Bisimulation Relation Restoration for Neural Networks Based On Knowledge Distillation

Improvement of Confidence and Knowledge Retention for Stroke Management Among Internal Medicine Trainees During an Institution-Specific, Protocol-Oriented Lecture Based Intervention

Author: LaBarbera, Vincent1    ; Sacchetti, Daniel1    1 Department of Neurology Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University

Publication info: LaBarbera, Vincent; Sacchetti, Daniel. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/improvement-confidence-knowledge-retention-stroke/docview/3173400754/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Acute stroke management is an essential component of neurology residency education. Internal medicine trainees are less likely to receive dedicated training in acute stroke care despite having to care for hospitalized patients with a stroke diagnosis. Background Acute stroke management is an essential component of neurology residency education. Internal medicine trainees are less likely to receive dedicated training in acute stroke care despite having to care for hospitalized patients with a stroke diagnosis.The objectives of this survey-based quality improvement study were to: 1) assess pre-existing confidence and knowledge about acute stroke care among internal medicine trainees and 2) measure change after an institution-specific, protocol-oriented "value added lecture" (intervention). Objective The objectives of this survey-based quality improvement study were to: 1) assess pre-existing confidence and knowledge about acute stroke care among internal medicine trainees and 2) measure change after an institution-specific, protocol-oriented "value added lecture" (intervention).Pre-intervention survey and knowledge assessment was given to internal medicine physicians, residents, and students, followed by the intervention on acute stroke management, during academic year 2019-2020. Post-intervention assessment was administered immediately post-intervention, and again at end of rotation. A 10-point Likert scale was used to indicate confidence. Statistics were performed using Student's T-Test. Methods Pre-intervention survey and knowledge assessment was given to internal medicine physicians, residents, and students, followed by the intervention on acute stroke management, during academic year 2019-2020. Post-intervention assessment was administered immediately post-intervention, and again at end of rotation. A 10-point Likert scale was used to indicate confidence. Statistics were performed using Student's T-Test.Fifty-one respondents participated, out of a possible 162 (31% participation rate); 13 (25%) of the 51 respondents completed the delayed post-intervention survey. Only twenty-six (51%) participants had previously received a lecture on acute stroke management. Respondents' knowledge and confidence on acute stroke management improved after intervention (p<0.0001), with no change in these scores by end of rotation (p=0.31). Forty-five (88%) respondents agreed or strongly agreed that a targeted stroke didactic was a useful part of internal medicine training. Results Fifty-one respondents participated, out of a possible 162 (31% participation rate); 13 (25%) of the 51 respondents completed the delayed post-intervention survey. Only twenty-six (51%) participants had previously received a lecture on acute stroke management. Respondents' knowledge and confidence on acute stroke management improved after intervention (p<0.0001), with no change in these scores by end of rotation (p=0.31). Forty-five (88%) respondents agreed or strongly agreed that a targeted stroke didactic was a useful part of internal medicine training.An institution-specific, protocol-oriented lecture improved stroke management knowledge and confidence among internal medicine trainees, particularly among earlier trainees. A dedicated stroke management lecture should be considered as an addition to internal medicine training programs' curricula. Conclusions An institution-specific, protocol-oriented lecture improved stroke management knowledge and confidence among internal medicine trainees, particularly among earlier trainees. A dedicated stroke management lecture should be considered as an addition to internal medicine training programs' curricula.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Vincent&amp;aulast=LaBarbera&amp;atitle=Improvement+of+Confidence+and+Knowledge+Retention+for+Stroke+Management+Among+Internal+Medicine+Trainees+During+an+Institution-Specific%2C+Protocol-Oriented+Lecture+Based+Intervention&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Brown+hospital+medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.56305%2F001c.91547&amp;title=Improvement+of+Confidence+and+Knowledge+Retention+for+Stroke+Management+Among+Internal+Medicine+Trainees+During+an+Institution-Specific%2C+Protocol-Oriented+Lecture+Based+Intervention&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=91547&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Vincent&amp;aulast=LaBarbera&amp;atitle=Improvement+of+Confidence+and+Knowledge+Retention+for+Stroke+Management+Among+Internal+Medicine+Trainees+During+an+Institution-Specific%2C+Protocol-Oriented+Lecture+Based+Intervention&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Brown+hospital+medicine&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.56305%2F001c.91547&amp;title=Improvement+of+Confidence+and+Knowledge+Retention+for+Stroke+Management+Among+Internal+Medicine+Trainees+During+an+Institution-Specific%2C+Protocol-Oriented+Lecture+Based+Intervention&amp;volume=3&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=91547&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

MultiVFL: A Training-Efficient Framework for Multiple Vertical Federated Learning

Author: Huang, Ju1; Zhang, Lan1; Cheng, Ding2; Huang, Dongbo2; Xu, Lan21 School of Computer Science and Technology, University of Science and Technology of China,Hefei,China2 Tencent,Shanghai,China

Publication info: Huang, Ju; Zhang, Lan; Cheng, Ding; Huang, Dongbo; Xu, Lan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/multivfl-training-efficient-framework-multiple/docview/3172326471/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 10th International Conference on Big Data Computing and Communications (BigCom) Conference Start Date: 2024, Aug. 9 Conference End Date: 2024, Aug. 11 Conference Location: Dalian, China Vertical Federated Learning (VFL) is an effective paradigm which matches the enterprises' demands of leveraging more valuable features to achieve better model performance while keeping their data decentralized. Training costs, especially communication costs among parties have always been one of the major bottlenecks in VFL. Almost all existing approaches is aimed at optimizing the overhead of a single VFL task. However, there are situations where a passive party cooperates with multiple active parties to jointly train VFL models task by task, which causing the passive party incurring significant duplication of training costs. In this scenario, because these methods tailored for single VFL task cannot leverage the inter-task correlations, they might be suboptimal in terms of optimization and the model's performance may also be less satisfactory. In this article, we focus on reducing the training overhead of the passive party in multiple VFL collaborations. We utilize all local data of the passive party, including data discarded in the VFL task, for unsupervised training to accelerate the convergence speed of VFL training. Some new problems arise due to the data heterogeneity between tasks and the issue of catastrophic forgetting in models. In order to solve these issues, we propose a training-efficient algorithm named MultiVFL for multiple VFL collaborations. MultiVFL adopt parameter-level knowledge retention and fine-tuning algorithm, motivated by the sparsity of the bottom model in VFL. Through this approach, MultiVFL is able to maintain efficient training across various scenarios. We conducted experiments on two datasets containing five tasks each, and the results indicate that MultiVFL can continuously and efficiently learn tasks in multiple rounds of VFL collaboration. Compared to traditional VFL methods, MultiVFL saves about 70% of training overhead on tabular datasets and 21% on image datasets with excellent model accuracy.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ju&amp;aulast=Huang&amp;atitle=MultiVFL%3A+A+Training-Efficient+Framework+for+Multiple+Vertical+Federated+Learning&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FBIGCOM65357.2024.00028&amp;title=MultiVFL%3A+A+Training-Efficient+Framework+for+Multiple+Vertical+Federated+Learning&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ju&amp;aulast=Huang&amp;atitle=MultiVFL%3A+A+Training-Efficient+Framework+for+Multiple+Vertical+Federated+Learning&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FBIGCOM65357.2024.00028&amp;title=MultiVFL%3A+A+Training-Efficient+Framework+for+Multiple+Vertical+Federated+Learning&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Student-Centered Learning Using Augmented Reality in Anatomy and Physiology Education

Author: Johnson, Cody1; Savara, Saurabh2; Gonzales, Edward2; Moore, Shawn3; Jones, Elizabeth4; Wu, Rui51 Computer Science East Carolina University, Greenville,Greenville,North Carolina,USA2 Computer Science East Carolina University,Greenville3 Surgery East Carolina University, Greenville,Greenville,North Carolina,USA4 Biology East Carolina University, Greenville,Greenville,North Carolina,USA5 Computer Science East Carolina University,Greenville,NC,27858

Publication info: Johnson, Cody; Savara, Saurabh; Gonzales, Edward; Moore, Shawn; Jones, Elizabeth; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/student-centered-learning-using-augmented-reality/docview/3171483280/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference (FIE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Oct. 13 Conference End Date: 2024, Oct. 16 Conference Location: Washington, DC, USA This research-to-practice paper described how a student-centered learning pedagogy and AR techniques are used to enhance Anatomy and Physiology undergraduate education. Throughout the evolution of biomedical and engineering education, teachers and students have experimented with various forms of learning platforms and techniques in hopes of enhancing the learning experience. However, these efforts have not always been interactive, leading to student burnout, disengagement, decreased knowledge retention, and lower grades. To tackle this issue, We propose a method to improve both Anatomy and Physiology education. Students can learn biomedical science as well as other engineering educational topics with a more interactive experience using our proposed method via AR device, i.e., HoloLens 2. This project used an exploratory method, which involves conducting user studies using HoloLens 2 as a medium to teach students course-related topics. This method is based on a Student-Centered Learning pedagogy and allows students to walk through course materials with different paths and paces based on the students' preferences, allowing us to investigate the relationship between information retention and the AR platform. Said user studies are conducted to collect qualitative data about students' learning outcomes and their opinions on our proposed method. Through user studies, we recruited 30 students to take part in the lesson plans created and curated by professors in the associated university. Students are given quizzes before taking part to test knowledge of the subjects that they have not been introduced to before and then are allowed to tackle modules at their own pace. They are then given the option to attempt modules at their discretion. This is due to the lesson plan being designed as a tree structure, with multiple pathways that can be navigated either upward or downwards depending on whether they have completed the prerequisite module. After studying the lessons provided, they are given a quiz in a virtual environment to test the knowledge that they have gained while using the device. When calculating the averages of both assessments, students on average had an improvement of 10 percent in scores after using our proposed method compared to the quiz scores collected before using the device. They were also given a survey on their thoughts concerning using the HoloLens 2 device after finishing the study where 96 percent of students believe that the tools and techniques from augmented reality are both exciting and would find it useful in the study of other disciplines. 90 percent of students also found that both listening and conversational skills are frequently utilized while using Augmented Reality.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Cody&amp;aulast=Johnson&amp;atitle=Student-Centered+Learning+Using+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+and+Physiology+Education&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893446&amp;title=Student-Centered+Learning+Using+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+and+Physiology+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Cody&amp;aulast=Johnson&amp;atitle=Student-Centered+Learning+Using+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+and+Physiology+Education&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893446&amp;title=Student-Centered+Learning+Using+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+and+Physiology+Education&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Towards Personalized Learning Environments: Using Machine Learning to Predict Students' Learning Preferences in a Mixed Reality Environment

Author: Tomori, Mariam1; Ogunseiju, Omobolanle1; Tummalapudi, Manideep2; Bangaru, Srikanth31 Georgia Institute of Technology,Building Construction,Atlanta,U.S.A2 California State University,Fresno,USA3 Inncircles Technology Inc,U.S.A

Publication info: Tomori, Mariam; Ogunseiju, Omobolanle; Tummalapudi, Manideep; Bangaru, Srikanth. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/towards-personalized-learning-environments-using/docview/3171482010/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference (FIE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Oct. 13 Conference End Date: 2024, Oct. 16 Conference Location: Washington, DC, USA This research-to-practice full paper describes the machine learning techniques for predicting students' learning preferences and cognitive load in a mixed reality environment. As the construction industry increasingly adopts sensing technologies, the demand for hands-on learning experiences in construction education becomes imperative. However, challenges arise in educating the future workforce due to limited access to construction sites for practical learning and the high costs associated with these technologies. To overcome these obstacles, educators are turning to virtual learning environments, such as mixed reality (MR), to provide engaging learning experiences. While MR has been utilized in construction education for simulating activities, the design of such learning environments often neglects to account for the varying learning preferences necessary for effective navigation and optimal learning outcomes. This makes it necessary to develop intelligent learning environments that can detect students' learning preferences and present information based on individual preferences. Extant studies have shown that eye movement data, particularly fixations from virtual learning environments, provide valuable insights into users' cognitive processes. Studies have also shown that leveraging machine learning algorithms enables the analysis and interpretation of eye-tracking data, offering deeper insights into students' learning preferences. In this study, nineteen undergraduate students participated in hands-on activities involving the implementation of sensing technologies within an MR learning environment. Questionnaires on learning preferences were used to assess individual learning preferences. By employing machine learning techniques on eye-tracking data and subjective evaluations of learning preferences, the study presents models that can detect students' learning preferences. The study compared performance metrics from three classifiers - Ensemble, Neural Network, and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and the Ensemble classifier was identified as the most accurate, achieving an accuracy of 83.3% for the test model. The findings highlight the potential of machine learning models in detecting learning preferences most effectively for the user's interactions. The classification models, when implemented in the MR environment, can identify users who may require additional support tailored to their specific learning preferences. Thereby enhancing their interaction with the MR learning environment. Understanding and accommodating diverse learning preferences in MR learning environments can offer personalized experiences for effective engagement and knowledge retention in construction education. By tailoring instructional methods to individual preferences, educators can create inclusive environments that foster deeper comprehension and maximize learning outcomes.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mariam&amp;aulast=Tomori&amp;atitle=Towards+Personalized+Learning+Environments%3A+Using+Machine+Learning+to+Predict+Students%27+Learning+Preferences+in+a+Mixed+Reality+Environment&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893418&amp;title=Towards+Personalized+Learning+Environments%3A+Using+Machine+Learning+to+Predict+Students%27+Learning+Preferences+in+a+Mixed+Reality+Environment&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mariam&amp;aulast=Tomori&amp;atitle=Towards+Personalized+Learning+Environments%3A+Using+Machine+Learning+to+Predict+Students%27+Learning+Preferences+in+a+Mixed+Reality+Environment&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893418&amp;title=Towards+Personalized+Learning+Environments%3A+Using+Machine+Learning+to+Predict+Students%27+Learning+Preferences+in+a+Mixed+Reality+Environment&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

WIP: Teaching Basic Concepts of Quantum Computing Using Scratch

Author: Rosa-Remedios, Carlos1; Caballero-Gil, Pino1; Escanez-Exposito, Daniel11 University of La Laguna,Department of Computer Engineering and Systems,Tenerife,Spain

Publication info: Rosa-Remedios, Carlos; Caballero-Gil, Pino; Escanez-Exposito, Daniel. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/wip-teaching-basic-concepts-quantum-computing/docview/3171481986/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference (FIE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Oct. 13 Conference End Date: 2024, Oct. 16 Conference Location: Washington, DC, USA This work-in-progress research paper presents an innovative learning methodology based on gamification and the concept of “building your own knowledge” to motivate and spark students' interest in quantum computing. Using the Scratch platform with younger high school students, basic quantum computing principles are taught through interactive mini-games, focusing on concepts like superposition and entanglement. For older students, a more formal methodology is proposed that uses the Bloch Sphere representation via the CreatiCode platform. This paper discusses an implementation of the proposal with high school groups, including statistical analysis and feedback collection to assess concept acquisition, strengths, weaknesses and student satisfaction. Data is gathered through questionnaires and interviews, enabling comparison with external test groups for comprehensive evaluation. This approach integrates computational thinking, gamification and visual knowledge construction, aligning with STEM education principles and fostering knowledge retention.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Carlos&amp;aulast=Rosa-Remedios&amp;atitle=WIP%3A+Teaching+Basic+Concepts+of+Quantum+Computing+Using+Scratch&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893288&amp;title=WIP%3A+Teaching+Basic+Concepts+of+Quantum+Computing+Using+Scratch&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Enhancing Engineering Education Through LLM-Driven Adaptive Quiz Generation: A RAG-Based Approach

Author: Gopi, Sreekanth1; Devananda Sreekanth1; Dehbozorgi, Nasrin21 Kennesaw State University,Department of Computer Science,Kennesaw,GA2 Kennesaw State University,Department of Software Engineering,Kennesaw,GA

Publication info: Gopi, Sreekanth; Devananda Sreekanth; Dehbozorgi, Nasrin. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/enhancing-engineering-education-through-llm/docview/3171481925/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference (FIE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Oct. 13 Conference End Date: 2024, Oct. 16 Conference Location: Washington, DC, USA This research-to-practice study aims to develop an Artificial Intelligence (AI) MCQ generation system for engineering students, with a focus on adaptive learning, educational technology, and innovative assessment tools, to enhance personalized learning. Engineering education faces significant academic performance challenges, with first-year retention rates in STEM fields ranging between 27% to 46%, largely due to poor academic achievements. Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs) identify misconceptions, reinforce knowledge retention, and offer efficient assessment methods for engineering education. This interactive method improves attention and memory retention, reinforces knowledge, and improves comprehension. In this context, the emergence of Large Language Models (LLMs) such as GPT-4 has marked a significant advancement. Our literature review method employed a systematic approach, analyzing peer-reviewed articles, conference papers, and authoritative reports to uncover the trends and challenges in AI-driven quiz generation. The notable gap identified in our literature review is the lack of LLM-based adaptive quiz generation methods specifically for engineering education. Our methodology involved sourcing relevant structured datasets, data pre-processing, embedding generation, vector database storage, hybrid-search retrieval, LLM query results feed, prompt engineering, and context-based response. In this research, we adopted Vectara as a vector database tool for its automatic data ingestion capabilities and seamless integration with generative AI applications. Prompt engineering involves a dual-prompt approach, where the Contextual Question Prompt formulates questions based on user topics and chat history, while the Answer Question Prompt manages MCQ responses with explanations, ensuring relevant and contextually accurate interactions. Evaluation includes topic relevancy, answer relevancy, and a contextual relevancy score. Preliminary results indicate promising results for the generation of accurate and contextually appropriate questions with minimal hallucinations. The quiz generation system was deployed using Streamlit cloud-based architecture to showcase the functionality. Looking forward, we aim to expand the dataset to include more diverse engineering disciplines and to refine the retrieval algorithms to better handle complex diagrams and mathematical expressions commonly found in engineering texts.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Sreekanth&amp;aulast=Gopi&amp;atitle=Enhancing+Engineering+Education+Through+LLM-Driven+Adaptive+Quiz+Generation%3A+A+RAG-Based+Approach&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893146&amp;title=Enhancing+Engineering+Education+Through+LLM-Driven+Adaptive+Quiz+Generation%3A+A+RAG-Based+Approach&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Sreekanth&amp;aulast=Gopi&amp;atitle=Enhancing+Engineering+Education+Through+LLM-Driven+Adaptive+Quiz+Generation%3A+A+RAG-Based+Approach&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893146&amp;title=Enhancing+Engineering+Education+Through+LLM-Driven+Adaptive+Quiz+Generation%3A+A+RAG-Based+Approach&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

An Approach to Spaced Repetition Methodology for Teaching Markup and Scripting Programming Languages

Author: Afonso Serafim Jacinto1    ; Francisco Petronio Alencar de Medeiros1    ; Matheus Pereira de Sousa1    1 Information Technology Graduate Program, Instituto Federal da Paraíba,João Pessoa,Brazil

Publication info: Afonso Serafim Jacinto; Francisco Petronio Alencar de Medeiros; Matheus Pereira de Sousa. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/approach-spaced-repetition-methodology-teaching/docview/3171481070/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference (FIE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Oct. 13 Conference End Date: 2024, Oct. 16 Conference Location: Washington, DC, USA Contribution: This research full paper investigates the use of Spaced Repetition (SR) methodology in teaching markup and scripting programming languages to assess its impact on academic performance, knowledge retention and student perception of the learning process. Background: There is a quest for strategies capable of supporting students and helping them achieve better learning outcomes. The SR strategy, rooted in Ebbinghaus’ Forgetting Curve, is widely utilized across multiple domains. This methodology has shown promising results in foreign language and medicine education, although it is not yet extensively explored in computer science education. Since its efficacy has been demonstrated notably in foreign language education, investigating its application within Computer and Engineering education disciplines could be beneficial, as programming languages share learning characteristics common to natural language. Research Questions: What is the impact of using SR methodology in teaching markup and scripting languages in relation to academic performance, knowledge retention and students’ perception of learning? Methodology: The methodological journey of this research included four phases: (1) Systematic literature review, (2) Development of an SR methodology approach for teaching markup and script languages, (3) Semi-structured interviews, and (4) Planning, execution and analysis of the field experiment. The statistical models used were the difference between means for measurements of the two samples and the chi-square test with two criteria. Findings: The results indicate significant differences between class grades, validating the influence of Interleaved Study with Spaced Repetition on improving participants' academic performance and content retention, compared to Concentrated Study with Massed Repetition. However, the results do not indicate that the teaching method has an influence on the students’ perception of learning.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Afonso+Serafim+Jacinto&amp;atitle=An+Approach+to+Spaced+Repetition+Methodology+for+Teaching+Markup+and+Scripting+Programming+Languages&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893444&amp;title=An+Approach+to+Spaced+Repetition+Methodology+for+Teaching+Markup+and+Scripting+Programming+Languages&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Afonso+Serafim+Jacinto&amp;atitle=An+Approach+to+Spaced+Repetition+Methodology+for+Teaching+Markup+and+Scripting+Programming+Languages&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FFIE61694.2024.10893444&amp;title=An+Approach+to+Spaced+Repetition+Methodology+for+Teaching+Markup+and+Scripting+Programming+Languages&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

The Effects of a Healthcare Simulation Escape Room on Clinical Judgment: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Author: Peltier, Jennifer    

Publication info: Peltier, Jennifer. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/effects-healthcare-simulation-escape-room-on/docview/3170654284/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: The predominant pedagogy of traditional lecture-based learning should include meaningful active content to foster clinical judgment, engagement, and knowledge retention. Innovative active learning strategies must be tested to understand if they can better facilitate nursing learners’ readiness for practice.  Aims: This research study investigated the impact of a healthcare simulation escape room as an innovative platform on individual and team clinical judgment to determine whether this active learning strategy can benefit nursing learners’ preparedness and increase clinical judgment.  Method: A randomized, double-blinded, waitlist control design was used to examine the effect of a healthcare simulation escape room on clinical judgment. Nursing learners participated in didactic learning, a healthcare simulation escape room, and an obstetric hemorrhage simulation as part of the maternal clinical course. The Lasater Clinical Judgment Rubric (LCJR) evaluated individual clinical judgment, and the modified Critical Behavior Checklist (CBC) evaluated group clinical judgment. A demographic survey with additional questions was collected to determine if any teams had prior knowledge of the experiences. The data from the observation checklists was analyzed using an independent t-test, an analysis of covariance (ANCOVA), and a multivariate analysis of covariance (MANOVA) to examine the difference between clinical judgment scores from the waitlist control and intervention groups. An alpha level of .05 was used in the statistical analysis. The demographic data was analyzed using descriptive statistics.  Results: The clinical judgment scores increased for individual and team participants who experienced the healthcare simulation escape room. The ANCOVA comparing group differences of the LCJR total scale score revealed that the intervention group ( M = 23.04 SD = 4.06) had significantly higher scores ( F (1,76) = 100.44, p < .001) on the LCJR total scale score than the waitlist control group ( M = 14.53, SD = 2.48) controlling for age and sex.). The participants who completed the healthcare simulation escape room ( M = 22, SD = 2.21) reported significantly higher levels of clinical judgment in the management of an obstetric hemorrhage than the participants who did not experience a healthcare simulation escape room ( M = 16.7, SD = 2.75), t (25) = -5.56, p < .001). Discussion: The study demonstrated that healthcare simulation escape rooms as an innovative platform can play a significant role in enhancing both individual and team clinical judgment. Clinical judgment is crucial for nursing students to provide high-quality, safe patient care, which is rooted in effective educational methodologies. Nursing education should intentionally craft teaching strategies that cater to the needs of contemporary learners while fostering the development of clinical judgment. Nurse educators are encouraged to explore and disseminate successful teaching strategies that build the knowledge, skills, and attitudes essential for cultivating clinical judgment. Further research is warranted to explore the relationship between other innovative platforms, such as the healthcare simulation escape rooms, and the advancement of clinical judgment.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Peltier&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=The+Effects+of+a+Healthcare+Simulation+Escape+Room+on+Clinical+Judgment%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798304985307&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Peltier&amp;atitle=&amp;stitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=The+Effects+of+a+Healthcare+Simulation+Escape+Room+on+Clinical+Judgment%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=9798304985307&amp;genre=dissertations&amp;

Ethnobotanical survey of medicinal and ritual plants utilized by the indigenous communities of Benguet province, Philippines

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/ethnobotanical-survey-medicinal-ritual-plants/docview/3168948091/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background The Sto. Niño site in Benguet province, Philippines was once a mining area that has now been transformed into an agricultural land. In this area, there has been significant integration of the three indigenous people (IPs) Ibaloi, Kankanaeys and Kalanguyas with the Ilocano community. These IPs safeguard biodiversity and traditional knowledge, including medicinal plant use. However, the documentation of these plant species and their medicinal applications has not been systematic, with the resultant loss of knowledge across generations. This study aims to document the medicinal and ritual plants used by the indigenous communities at the site, in order to preserve and disseminate traditional medicinal knowledge that would otherwise be lost. Methods Ethnobotanical data were collected in Sto. Niño, Brgy. Ambassador, Municipality of Tublay, Benguet, Philippines, and collected through semi-structured interviews, together with focus group discussions (FGD). A total of 100 residents (39 male and 61 female) were interviewed. Among them, 12 were key interviewees, including community elders and farmers, while the rest were selected through the convenience and snowball technique. Demographic information collected from the interviewees included age, gender, and occupation. Ethnobotanical information collected focused on medicinal plants, including the specific parts of plants used, methods of preparation, modes of treatment, and the types of ailments treated. Ethnobotanical quantitative indices of the relative frequency of citations (RFC) and informant consensus factor (ICF) were calculated to evaluate the plant species that were utilized by the community. Results A total of 28 medicinal plants from 20 different families and 6 ritual plants from 5 different families were documented. Asteraceae, Poaceae, and Lamiaceae (10.71%) family are the most mentioned medicinal plant species, followed by Myrtaceae and Euphorbiaceae (7.14%). The most widely used growth form were herbs (46.4%), while leaves (61.5%) were the most utilized plant part, and the preparation of a decoction (62.2%) was the most preferred method of processing and application. The medicinal plants were most commonly utilized for wound-healing, cough and colds, stomachache and kidney trouble, whereas ritual plants were largely used for healing, protection, and funeral ceremonies. Conclusion This study marks the first report on the medicinal and ritual plants used by a group of indigenous communities in Sto. Niño, Brgy. Ambassador, Tublay, Benguet Province. The data collected show that plant species belonging to the Asteraceae, Poaceae, and Lamiaceae family were the most mentioned and should be further evaluated by pharmacological analysis to assess their wider use for medicinal treatment.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=&amp;atitle=Ethnobotanical+survey+of+medicinal+and+ritual+plants+utilized+by+the+indigenous+communities+of+Benguet+province%2C+Philippines&amp;stitle=Tropical+Medicine+and+Health&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs41182-024-00624-1&amp;title=Ethnobotanical+survey+of+medicinal+and+ritual+plants+utilized+by+the+indigenous+communities+of+Benguet+province%2C+Philippines&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=&amp;atitle=Ethnobotanical+survey+of+medicinal+and+ritual+plants+utilized+by+the+indigenous+communities+of+Benguet+province%2C+Philippines&amp;stitle=Tropical+Medicine+and+Health&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs41182-024-00624-1&amp;title=Ethnobotanical+survey+of+medicinal+and+ritual+plants+utilized+by+the+indigenous+communities+of+Benguet+province%2C+Philippines&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=1&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

O uso de jogos didáticos no ensino da geografia no ensino secundário

Author: da Silva Azevedo Vieira, Catarina Sofia

Publication info: da Silva Azevedo Vieira, Catarina Sofia. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/dissertations-theses/o-uso-de-jogos-didáticos-no-ensino-da-geografia/docview/3168226272/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Atualmente, os professores sentem a necessidade de adaptar as suas práticas pedagógicas às demandas contemporâneas para conseguirem um maior envolvimento dos alunos na sua disciplina. Nesse sentido, foi conduzida a experiência educativa intitulada “O uso de Jogos Didáticos no ensino da Geografia no Ensino Secundário”, focada na Escola Secundária de Vila Verde. Esta investigação-ação analisa a eficácia dos jogos didáticos, tanto analógicos quanto digitais, desenvolvidos pela autora e pelas editoras escolares, no processo de ensino-aprendizagem, destacando os benefícios e desafios que estes podem apresentar, no Ensino Secundário. Para alcançar os objetivos propostos, foi aplicado um questionário para percecionar a opinião dos alunos sobre o uso desses jogos em sala de aula, além de serem observados os resultados dessas atividades, e a atitude dos alunos durante a sua realização. Além disso, foram também analisados alguns jogos das editoras escolares, de forma a compreender a sua adequação e viabilidade em ambiente educacional. Os dados recolhidos revelam que a maioria dos alunos prefere aulas que incluam jogos didáticos, destacando que essas atividades aumentam a atenção, interesse e retenção de conhecimento. A análise dos resultados permitiu identificar áreas de aprimoramento e orientar o desenvolvimento de estratégias pedagógicas mais eficazes. Em suma, a presente investigação-ação, enfatiza a importância dos jogos didáticos como ferramentas complementares no ensino da Geografia, sugerindo que o seu uso pode contribuir significativamente para o envolvimento dos alunos e melhoria dos resultados educacionais, mesmo no ensino Secundário. A implementação de jogos didáticos é vista como uma estratégia promissora para tornar a aprendizagem mais dinâmica e interativa. Esta abordagem atende às demandas contemporâneas por práticas pedagógicas inovadoras, mesmo em ciclos de estudo caracterizado pela seriedade dos Exames Nacionais. Alternate abstract: Currently, teachers feel the need to adapt their pedagogical practices to contemporary demands in order to achieve greater student engagement in their discipline. In this regard, an educational experiment entitled "The Use of Educational Games in Geography Education in Secondary School" was conducted, focusing on Vila Verde Secondary School. This action research examines the effectiveness of educational games, both analog and digital, developed by the author and educational publishers, in the teaching-learning process, highlighting the benefits and challenges they may present in secondary education. To achieve the stated objectives, a questionnaire was administered to gauge students' opinions on the use of these games in the classroom, alongside observation of the outcomes of these activities and students' attitudes during their implementation. Additionally, games from educational publishers were analyzed to understand their suitability and feasibility in an educational environment. The collected data reveal that the majority of students prefer classes that incorporate educational games, noting that these activities enhance attention, interest, and knowledge retention. Analysis of the results has identified areas for improvement and guided the development of more effective pedagogical strategies. In summary, this action research underscores the importance of educational games as supplementary tools in geography education, suggesting that their use can significantly contribute to student engagement and educational outcomes improvement, even in secondary education. Implementing educational games is seen as a promising strategy to make learning more dynamic and interactive. This approach meets contemporary demands for innovative pedagogical practices, even in educational cycles characterized by the seriousness of national examinations.

Token Embedding Graph Neural Network for Paper Classification

Author: Cai, Shuchen1; Gan, Xiaoying11 School of Electronic Information and Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University,Shanghai,China

Publication info: Cai, Shuchen; Gan, Xiaoying. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/token-embedding-graph-neural-network-paper/docview/3164463754/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE) Conference Start Date: 2024, Nov. 8 Conference End Date: 2024, Nov. 10 Conference Location: Wuhu, China The topic classification task on academic papers significantly contributes to the analysis of valuable papers. Classic methods first build a paper citation graph and then classify each paper node with a graph neural network (GNN). Some successors notice the rich semantics within the text features, namely the title and abstract of one paper, and start to extract the node representation from a text attributed graph (TAG). But the heterogeneity between graph topology and text sequence requires the representation learning algorithm to aggregate knowledge from both sides. Existing works embed the text feature in the corresponding node directly with a separate language model, so as to couple the knowledge in a cascading style. However, this text embedding algorithm faces a severe problem on calculation complexity because of the coupling. Given that the complexity of GNN grows exponentially as the number of layers increases, the high cost of the language model is further amplified to an intolerable degree. To conquer this challenge, we propose the token embedding graph neural network (TEGNN). Instead of cascading the language model and GNN, a shared token embedding layer is introduced to serve as the knowledge link between them. This structure decouples two modules without any knowledge loss, decreasing the complexity considerably. Experiments on the large-scale dataset prove the enhancement of efficiency. Compared with baseline algorithms, TEGNN decreases the training time by 70.17% on condition that the classification accuracy is increased by 1.04%.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Shuchen&amp;aulast=Cai&amp;atitle=Token+Embedding+Graph+Neural+Network+for+Paper+Classification&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FICAICE63571.2024.10864147&amp;title=Token+Embedding+Graph+Neural+Network+for+Paper+Classification&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Shuchen&amp;aulast=Cai&amp;atitle=Token+Embedding+Graph+Neural+Network+for+Paper+Classification&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FICAICE63571.2024.10864147&amp;title=Token+Embedding+Graph+Neural+Network+for+Paper+Classification&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Subject: Semantics; Heterogeneity; Topology; Classification; Graph neural networks; Neural networks; Nodes; Citation analysis; Artificial intelligence; Algorithms; Complexity; Machine learning; Graphical representations; Knowledge representation; Embedding

Transformative Pedagogies: Educational Innovations in Cybersecurity

Author: Zenzo Polite Ncube1; Mpofu, Nontokozo2; Nxumalo, Madoda A11 University of Eswatini,Department of Computer Science,Kwaluseni,Eswatini2 Sol Plaatje University,Department of Computer Science,Kimberley,South Africa

Publication info: Zenzo Polite Ncube; Mpofu, Nontokozo; Nxumalo, Madoda A. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/transformative-pedagogies-educational-innovations/docview/3161368704/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Conference Title: 2024 4th International Multidisciplinary Information Technology and Engineering Conference (IMITEC) Conference Start Date: 2024, Nov. 27 Conference End Date: 2024, Nov. 29 Conference Location: Vanderbijlpark, South Africa As the digital landscape undergoes continual transformation, the necessity for adept cybersecurity professionals has reached unprecedented levels. This paper investigates the convergence of education and cybersecurity. It offers a thorough analysis of avant-garde pedagogical approaches geared towards equipping the forthcoming generation of cyber defenders. Our study delves into cutting-edge educational strategies that transcend conventional cybersecurity curricula. It embraces dynamic methodologies such as hands-on learning, immersive simulations, and collaborative problem-solving. Moreover, we explore the seamless integration of emerging technologies that include virtual labs, gamification, and interactive scenarios in order to foster the cultivation of practical skills. Furthermore, this study evaluates the tangible impacts of educational innovations on knowledge retention, skills development, and adaptability to the ever-evolving realm of cyber threats. Through the examination of case studies and empirical evidence gathered, we spotlight the successful implementations of these innovations across diverse educational landscapes, spanning from academic institutions to professional training programs. In addition to the above, our research dissects the pivotal roles played by mentorship, industry partnerships, and real-world applications in nurturing a holistic educational environment. By unravelling the symbiotic relationship between academia and industry, we ensure that educational advancements remain finely attuned to the dynamic demands of the cybersecurity landscape.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Zenzo+Polite+Ncube&amp;atitle=Transformative+Pedagogies%3A+Educational+Innovations+in+Cybersecurity&amp;stitle=The+Institute+of+Electrical+and+Electronics+Engineers%2C+Inc.+%28IEEE%29+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FIMITEC60221.2024.10851040&amp;title=Transformative+Pedagogies%3A+Educational+Innovations+in+Cybersecurity&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2024&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;
